‚ÄúHujus qu√¶stionis duplex solutio est. [Œ§Œø·ø¶œÑŒøœÖ Œ¥ŒπœÑœÑ·Ω¥ ·ºÇŒΩ Œµ·º¥ŒΩ ·º° Œª·ΩªœÉŒµŒπœÇ.] Aut enim non recipimus Marci testimonium, quod in raris fertur [œÉœÄŒ±ŒΩ·Ω∑œâœÉ ·ºîŒΩ œÑŒπœÉŒπ œÜŒµœÅ·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒ±] Evangeliis, omnibus Gr√¶ci√¶ libris pene hec capitulum [œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫ŒµœÜ·Ω±ŒªŒ±ŒπŒøŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏] in fine non habentibus; [·ºêŒΩ œÑŒøœÖœÑ·ø∑ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÉœáŒµŒ¥·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ ·ºÖœÄŒ±œÉŒπ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥·Ω≥Œ≥œÅŒ±œÄœÑŒ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ]; pr√¶sertim cum diversa atque contraria Evangelistis ceteris narrare videntur [Œº·Ω±ŒªŒπœÉœÑŒ± Œµ·º¥œÄŒµœÅ ·ºîœáŒøŒπŒµŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒªŒøŒ≥·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÑ·øá œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒªŒøŒπœÄ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπœÉœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·Ω∑·æ≥.] Aut hoc respondendum, quod uterque verum dixerit [·ºêŒ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±ŒΩ œÄŒ±œÅŒ±Œ¥ŒµŒ∫œÑ·Ω≥Œ±ŒΩ ·ΩëœÄ·Ω±œÅœóŒµŒπŒΩ ... œÉœÖŒ≥œáœâœÅŒøœÖŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖ Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ ·ºÄŒªŒ∑Œ∏Œø·ø¶œÇ.] Matth√¶us, quando Dominus surrexerit vespere sabbati: Marcus autem, quando tum viderit Maria Magdalena, id est, mane prima sabbati. Ita enim distinguendum est, Cum autem resurrexisset: [ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÉœÑŒøŒª·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒΩœâœÉœÑ·Ω≥ŒøŒΩ ·ºàŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ Œ¥·Ω≥:] et, parumper, spiritu coarctato inferendum, Prima sabbati mane apparuit Mari√¶ Magdalen√¶: [Œµ·º∂œÑŒ± ·ΩëœÄŒøœÉœÑ·Ω∑ŒæŒ±ŒΩœÑŒµœÇ ·ø•Œ∑œÑ·Ω≥ŒøŒΩ, Œ†œÅœâŒπ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá.] Ut qui vespere sabbati, juxta Matth√¶um surrexerat, [œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∑ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·Ω∑·ø≥, ·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ, œÑŒøœÑŒµ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºêŒ≥·ΩµŒ≥ŒµœÅŒ±œÑŒø.] ipse mane prima sabbati, juxta Marcum, apparuerit Mari√¶ Magdalen√¶. [œÄœÅŒø·Ω∑ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá.] Quod quidem et Joannes Evangelista significat, mane Eum alterius diei visum esse demonstrans.‚Äù [œÑŒø·ø¶œÑŒø Œ≥Œø·ø¶ŒΩ ·ºêŒ¥·ΩµŒªœâœÉŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ΩÅ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑œÇ œÄœÅŒø·Ω∑ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏œÇ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·Ω¶œÜŒ∏Œ±Œπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·ΩµœÉŒ±œÇ.]

94.

·º†œÅ·ΩΩœÑŒ±œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ œÄœÅ·ø∂œÑŒøŒΩ,‚ÄîŒ†·ø∂œÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·Ω∑·ø≥ ·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ œÜŒ±·Ω∑ŒΩŒµœÑŒ±Œπ ·ºêŒ≥ŒµŒ≥ŒµœÅŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÇ ·ΩÅ Œ£œâœÑ·Ω¥œÅ, œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·ø∑ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫·ø≥ œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ; [Eusebius ad Marinum,(Mai, iv. 255.)]

Primum qu√¶ris,‚ÄîCur Matth√¶us dixerit, vespere autem Sabbati illucescente in una Sabbate Dominum resurrexisse; et Marcus mane resurrectionem ejus factam esse commemorat. [Hieronymus ad Hedibiam, (Opp. i. 818-9.)]

Œ†·ø∂œÇ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ, ·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·ºÅœÑœâŒΩ ·º° ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·Ω¥ œÑŒµŒ∏ŒµŒ±Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒ∑ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒπŒΩ, Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑ŒΩ ·º° Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω¥ ·ºëœÉœÑ·ø∂œÉŒ± Œ∫ŒªŒ±·Ω∑ŒµŒπ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∑ ŒºŒΩŒ∑ŒºŒµ·Ω∑·ø≥ œÑ·øá Œº·Ω∑·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ. [Ut supr√†, p. 257.]

Quomodo, juxta Matth√¶um, vespere Sabbati, Maria Magdalene vidit Dominum resurgentem; et Joannes Evangelista refert eam mane una sabbati juxta sepulcrum fiere? [Ut supr√†, p. 819.]

Œ†·ø∂œÇ, Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ, ·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·ºÅœÑœâŒΩ ·º° ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·Ω¥ ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÑŒªŒªŒ∑œÇ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ ·ºÅœàŒ±Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒ∑ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒøœÉ·ø∂ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ£œâœÑ·øÜœÅŒøœÇ, ·º° Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω¥ œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·ºÄŒ∫Œø·ΩªŒµŒπ Œº·Ωµ ŒºŒøœÖ ·ºÖœÄœÑŒøœÖ, Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑ŒΩ. [Ut supr√†, p. 262.]

Quomodo, juxta Matth√¶um, Maria Magdalene vespere Sabbati cum alter√¢ Mari√¢ advoluta sit pedibus Salvatoris; cum, secundum Joannem, audierit √† Domino, Noli me tangere. [Ut supr√†, p. 821.]

109.

113.

The following is the original of what is given above:‚Äî·ºòœÄŒµŒπŒ¥·Ω¥ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºîŒΩ œÑŒπœÉŒπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ œÄœÅ·ΩπœÉŒ∫ŒµŒπœÑŒ±Œπ œÑ·ø∑ œÄŒ±œÅ·ΩπŒΩœÑŒπ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑·ø≥, ‚Äú·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑, ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ (see below) ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øÜ ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá,‚Äù Œ¥ŒøŒ∫Œµ·øñ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑŒø·ø¶œÑŒø Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÜœâŒΩŒµ·øñŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ ·ΩëœÄ·Ω∏ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·Ω∑ŒøœÖ Œµ·Ω∂œÅŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩ·ø≥, ·Ω≤œÅŒø·ø¶ŒºŒµŒΩ ·Ω°œÇ Œ¥œÖŒΩŒ±œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÄŒµ·øñŒΩ ·ΩÖœÑŒπ ŒΩŒµŒΩ·ΩπŒ∏ŒµœÖœÑŒ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫·ø≥ œÑŒµŒªŒµœÖœÑŒ±·øñŒøŒΩ ·ºîŒΩ œÑŒπœÉŒπ œÜŒµœÅ·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒΩ. œÄŒª·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºµŒΩŒ± Œº·Ω¥ Œ¥·ΩπŒæœâŒºŒµŒΩ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∏ ·ºïœÑŒøŒπŒºŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±œÜŒµ·ΩªŒ≥ŒµŒπŒΩ, Œø·ΩîœÑœâœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒΩœâœÉ·ΩπŒºŒµŒ∏Œ±; ‚Äú·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ Œ¥·Ω≤,‚Äù Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÉœÑ·Ω∑ŒæŒ±ŒΩœÑŒµœÇ ·ºêœÄ·Ω±Œ≥œâŒºŒµŒΩ, ‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá.‚Äù ·ºµŒΩŒ± [The extract from Victor is continued below in the right hand column: the left exhibiting the text of Eusebius ‚Äúad Marinum.‚Äù] [Transcriber's Note: The extracts will be on alternating paragraphs.]

(Eusebius.) œÑ·Ω∏ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ ‚Äú·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ,‚Äù ·ºÄŒΩ[Œ±œÄ·Ω≥ŒºœàœâŒºŒµŒΩ?] ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∑ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·Ω∑·ø≥ ‚Äú·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ.‚Äù (œÑ·ΩπœÑŒµ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºêŒ≥·ΩµŒ≥ŒµœÅœÑŒø.) œÑ·Ω∏ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºëŒæ·øÜœÇ, ·ºëœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±œÇ ·ΩÑŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ±ŒΩŒø·Ω∑Œ±œÇ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÉœÑŒ±œÑŒπŒ∫·Ω∏ŒΩ, œÉœÖŒΩ·Ω±œàœâŒºŒµŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºêœÄŒπŒªŒµŒ≥ŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒπœÇ.

(Victor.) œÑ·Ω∏ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ ‚Äú·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ,‚Äù ·Ω∞ŒΩŒ±œÄ·Ω≥ŒºœàœâŒºŒµŒΩ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∑ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·Ω∑·ø≥ ‚Äú·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ.‚Äù (œÑ·ΩπœÑŒµ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºêŒ≥Œ∑Œ≥·Ω≥œÅŒ∏Œ±Œπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÄŒπœÉœÑŒµ·ΩªŒøŒºŒµŒΩ.) œÑ·Ω∏ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºëŒæ·øÜœÇ, ·ºëœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±œÇ ·ΩÑŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ±ŒΩŒø·Ω∑Œ±œÇ œÄŒ±œÅŒ±œÉœÑŒ±œÑŒπŒ∫·Ω∏ŒΩ, œÉœÖŒΩ·Ω±œàœâŒºŒµŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºêœÄŒπŒªŒµŒ≥ŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒπœÇ;

(Eusebius.) (‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑‚Äù Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ‚ÄúœÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá.‚Äù)

(Victor.) (œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ‚Äú·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ‚Äù Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ ·ºêŒ≥Œ±Œ≥ŒµœÅŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒΩ ·º±œÉœÑŒøœÅŒµ·øñ ‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑‚Äù ·ºëœâœÅŒ±Œ∫·Ω≥ŒΩŒ±Œπ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·ΩµŒΩ.)

(Eusebius.) œÑŒø·ø¶œÑŒø Œ≥Œø·ø¶ŒΩ ·ºêŒ¥·ΩµŒªœâœÉŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ΩÅ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑œÇ ‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑‚Äù Œ∫Œ±·Ω∑ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏œÇ ‚ÄúœÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ‚Äù ·Ω§œÜŒ∏Œ±Œπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·ΩµœÉŒ±œÇ.

(Victor.) œÑŒø·ø¶œÑŒø Œ≥Œø·ø¶ŒΩ ·ºêŒ¥·ΩµŒªœâœÉŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒµœÇ, ‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑‚Äù Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏œÇ ‚ÄúœÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ‚Äù ·Ω§œÜŒ∏Œ±Œπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·ΩµœÉŒ±œÇ.

[31 words here omitted.]

(Eusebius.) ·Ω°œÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∑œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·ΩªœÑŒøŒπœÇ Œ∫Œ±ŒπœÅŒø·Ω∫œÇ Œ¥·ΩªŒø; œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÉŒµœâœÇ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ‚Äú·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ.‚Äù œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ£œâœÑ·øÜœÅŒøœÇ ·ºêœÄŒπœÜŒ±ŒΩŒµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ, œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ‚ÄúœÄœÅœâ·Ω∑.‚Äù

(Victor.) ·Ω°œÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∑œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·ΩªœÑŒøŒπœÇ Œ∫Œ±ŒπœÅŒø·Ω∫œÇ Œ¥·ΩªŒø; œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÉŒµœâœÇ, œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ‚Äú·ΩÄœà·Ω≤ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ;‚Äù œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ£œâœÑ·øÜœÅŒøœÇ ·ºêœÄŒπœÜŒ±ŒΩŒµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ, œÑ·Ω∏ ‚ÄúœÄœÅŒø·Ω∑.‚Äù

[Eusebius, apud Mai, iv. p. 256.]

[Victor Antioch, ed. Cramer, i. p. 444-5: (with a few slight emendations of the text from Evan. Cod. Reg. 178.)]

Note, that Victor twice omits the word œÄœÅ·ø∂œÑŒøŒΩ, and twice reads œÑ·øá ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ, (instead of œÄœÅ·ø∂œÑ·øÉ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ), only because Eusebius had inadvertently (three times) done the same thing in the place from which Victor is copying. See Mai. Nova P. P. Bibl. iv. p. 256, line 19 and 26: p. 257 line 4 and 5.

117.
How shrewdly was it remarked by Matthaei, eighty years ago,‚Äî‚ÄúScholia certe, in quibus de integritate hujus loci dubitatur, omnia ex uno fonte promanarunt. Ex eodem fonte Hieronymum etiam hausisse intelligitur ex ejus loco quem laudavit Wetst. ad ver. 9.‚ÄîSimiliter Scholiast√¶ omnes in principio hujus Evangelii in disputatione de lectione ·ºêŒΩ ·º°œÉŒ±·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·ø∑ œÄœÅŒøœÜ·ΩµœÑŒ∑ ex uno pendent. Fortasse Origenes auctor est hujus dubitationis.‚Äù (N.T. vol. ii. p. 270.)‚ÄîThe reader is invited to remember what was offered above in p. 47 (line 23.)
118.
It is not often, I think, that one finds in MSS. a point actually inserted after ·ºàŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÇ Œ¥·Ω≥. Such a point is found, however, in Cod. 34 ( = Coisl. 195,) and Cod. 22 ( = Reg. 72,) and doubtless in many other copies.

It is plain why the scribe of ◊ê wrote ŒµœÄŒ±ŒΩœâ Œ±œÖœÑŒøœÖ œâœÇ Œ±œÉœÑœÅŒ±œÄŒ∑.‚ÄîThe next is from S. Luke xxiv. 31:‚Äî

ŒëŒ† ŒëŒ•Œ§Œ©Œù ŒöŒëŒô [ŒëŒù

127.

In this way, (at S. John xvii. 15, 16), the obviously corrupt reading of Cod. B (ŒπŒΩŒ± œÑŒ∑œÅŒ∑œÉŒ∑œÇ Œ±œÖœÑŒøœÖœÇ ŒµŒ∫ œÑŒøœÖ Œ∫ŒøœÉŒºŒøœÖ)‚Äîwhich, however, was the reading of the copy used by Athanasius (Opp. p. 1035: al. ed. p. 825)‚Äîis explained:‚Äî

ŒïŒö Œ§ŒüŒ• [Œ†ŒüŒùŒóŒ°ŒüŒ•.
ŒïŒö Œ§ŒüŒ•] ŒöŒüŒ£ŒúŒüŒ•
ŒüŒ•Œö ŒïŒôŒ£ŒôŒù ŒöŒëŒòŒ©Œ£

Thus also is explained why B (with ◊ê, A, D, L) omits a precious clause in S. Luke xxiv. 42:‚Äî

ŒüŒ†Œ§ŒüŒ• ŒúŒïŒ°ŒüŒ£ ŒöŒëŒô
[ŒëŒ†Œü ŒúŒïŒõŒôŒ£Œ£Œô
ŒüŒ• ŒöŒóŒ°ŒôŒüŒ• ŒöŒëŒô]
ŒõŒëŒíŒ©Œù ŒïŒùŒ©Œ†ŒôŒüŒù

And why the same MSS. (all but A) omit an important clause in S. Luke xxiv. 53:‚Äî

ŒïŒù Œ§Œ© ŒôŒïŒ°Œ© [ŒëŒôŒù
ŒüŒ•ŒùŒ§ŒïŒ£ ŒöŒëŒô] ŒïŒ•ŒõŒü
ŒìŒüŒ•ŒùŒ§ŒïŒ£ Œ§ŒüŒù ŒòŒóŒüŒù

And why B (with ◊ê, L) omits an important clause in the history of the Temptation (S. Luke iv. 5) :‚Äî

ŒöŒëŒô ŒëŒùŒëŒìŒëŒìŒ©Œù ŒëŒ•
Œ§ŒüŒù [ŒïŒôŒ£ ŒüŒ°ŒüŒ£ Œ•Œ®Œó
ŒõŒüŒù] ŒïŒîŒôŒûŒïŒù ŒëŒ•Œ§Œ©

128.

In this way the famous omission (◊ê, B, L) of the word Œ¥ŒµœÖœÑŒµœÅŒøœÄœÅ·ΩΩœÑ·ø≥, in S. Luke vi. 1, is (to say the least) capable of being explained:‚Äî

ŒïŒìŒïŒùŒïŒ§Œü Œî Œï ŒïŒù Œ£ŒëŒò

and of œÖŒπŒøœÖ ŒíŒ±œÅŒ±œáŒπŒøœÖ (◊ê) in S. Matth. xxvii. 35:‚Äî

142.
Note, that it is a mistake for the advocates of this reading to claim the Latin versions as allies. ·ºàœÄŒµŒ∫œÅ·Ω∑Œ∏Œ∑ ·ºêŒ∫Œµ·øñŒΩŒøœÇ, ·ºåŒΩŒ∏œÅœâœÄŒøœÇ ŒªŒµŒ≥·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒø·ø¶œÇ Œ∫.œÑ.Œª. is not ‚ÄúRespondit, Ille homo qui dicitur Jesus,‚Äù (as both Tischendorf and Tregelles assume;) but ‚ÄúRespondit ille, Homo,‚Äù &c.,‚Äîas in verses 25 and 36.

144.
The following may be added from Cod. ◊ê:‚ÄîŒºŒµŒ≥·Ω±ŒªŒøŒπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ (in S. Mark x. 42) changed into Œ≤Œ±œÉŒπŒªŒµŒπœÇ: ŒµŒπœÄŒµŒΩ (in S. Lu. ii. 37) for ·ΩÄŒ≥Œ¥ŒøŒ∑Œ∫: and ŒµœâœÅŒ±Œ∫ŒµŒΩ œÉŒµ (in S. Jo. viii. 57) for ·ºë·ΩΩœÅŒ±Œ∫Œ±œÇ:‚Äîin all which four readings Cod. ◊ê is without support. [Scrivener, Coll. Cod. Sin. p. li.] The epithet ŒºŒµŒ≥Œ±ŒΩ, introduced (in the same codex) before Œª·Ω∑Œ∏ŒøŒΩ in S. Mark xv. 46; and Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÄŒ±œÑœÅŒπŒ±œÇ inserted into the phrase ·ºêŒæ Œø·º¥Œ∫ŒøœÖ ŒîŒ±Œ≤·Ω∑Œ¥ in S. Lu. i. 27,‚Äîare two more specimens of mistaken officiousness. In the same infelicitous spirit, Cod. B and Cod. ◊ê concur in omitting ·º∞œÉœáœÖœÅ·ΩπŒΩ (S. Matt. xiv. 30), and in substituting œÄœÖŒ∫ŒΩŒ± for œÄœÖŒ≥Œº·øá, and œÅŒ±ŒΩœÑŒπœÉœâŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ for Œ≤Œ±œÄœÑ·Ω∑œÉœâŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ in S. Mark vii. 3 and 4:‚Äîwhile the interpolation of œÑŒ±œÉœÉŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ after ·ºêŒæŒøœÖœÉ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ in S. Matth. viii. 9, because of the parallel place in S. Luke's Gospel; and the substitution of Œ±ŒΩŒ∏œÅœâœÄŒøœÇ Œ±œÖœÉœÑŒ∑œÅŒøœÇ ŒµŒπ (from S. Luke xix. 21) for œÉŒ∫ŒªŒ∑œÅ·Ω∏œÇ Œµ·º∂ ·ºÑŒΩŒ∏œÅœâœÄŒøœÇ in S. Matth. xxv. 24, are proofs that yet another kind of corrupting influence has been here at work besides those which have been already specified.

146.
Add to the authorities commonly appealed to for ·ºêŒæŒµŒªŒ∏. Chrys.^834 (twice,) (also quoted in Cramer's Cat. 241). The mistake adverted to in the text is at least as old as the time of Eusebius, (Mai, iv. p. 264 = 287), who asks,‚ÄîŒ†·ø∂œÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω± œÑ·ø∑ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏·Ω±Œπ·ø≥ ·º° ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·Ω¥ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑Œ± ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÑŒªŒªŒ∑œÇ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ ·ºîŒæœâ œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒºŒΩ·ΩµŒºŒ±œÑŒøœÇ ·ºë·ΩΩœÅŒ±Œ∫ŒµŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºïŒΩŒ± ·ºÑŒ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒøŒΩ ·ºêœÄŒπŒ∫Œ±Œ∏·ΩµŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ Œª·Ω∑Œ∏·ø≥ œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒºŒΩ·ΩµŒºŒ±œÑŒøœÇ, Œ∫.œÑ.Œª.
147.
Tischendorf accordingly is forced, for once, to reject the reading of his oracle ◊ê,‚Äîwitnessed to though it be by Origen and Eusebius. His discussion of the text in this place is instructive and even diverting. How is it that such an instance as the present does not open the eyes of Prejudice itself to the danger of pinning its faith to the consentient testimony even of Origen, of Eusebius, and of Cod. ◊ê?... The reader is reminded of what was offered above, in the lower part of p. 49.
148.
A similar perversion of the truth of Scripture is found at S. Luke iv. 44, (cf. the parallel place, S. Matth. iv. 23: S. Mark i. 89). It does not mend the matter to find ◊ê supported this time by Codd. B, C, L, Q, R.
149.
S. Lu. xxiii. 45:‚Äî·ΩÖœÄŒµœÅ Œø·ΩêŒ¥·Ω≥œÄŒøœÑŒµ œÄœÅ·ΩπœÑŒµœÅŒøŒΩ œÉœÖŒΩ·Ω≥Œ≤Œ∑, ·ºÄŒªŒª·æΩ ·º¢ ·ºêŒΩ Œë·º∞Œ≥·ΩªœÄœÑœâ Œº·ΩπŒΩŒøŒΩ, ·ΩÖœÑŒµ œÑ·Ω∏ œÄ·Ω±œÉœáŒ± œÑŒµŒªŒµ·øñœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ ·ºîŒºŒµŒªŒªŒµ; Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºêŒ∫Œµ·øñŒΩŒ± œÑŒø·ΩªœÑœâŒΩ œÑ·ΩªœÄŒøœÇ ·º¶ŒΩ. (Chrys. vii. 824 c.)
150.
·ΩÖœÄœâœÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œº·Ω¥ Œµ·º∞œÄœâœÉ·Ω∑ œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ ·ºîŒ∫ŒªŒµŒπœàŒπŒΩ Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ≥ŒµŒ≥ŒµŒΩŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒΩ, ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·øá œÑŒµœÉœÉŒ±œÅŒµœÉŒ∫Œ±ŒπŒ¥ŒµŒ∫·Ω±œÑŒ∑ ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÉŒµŒª·ΩµŒΩŒ∑œÇ Œ≥·ºêŒ≥ŒøŒΩŒµ œÑ·Ω∏ œÉŒ∫·ΩπœÑŒøœÇ:‚Äî·ΩÖœÑŒµ ·ºîŒ∫ŒªŒµŒπœàŒπŒΩ œÉœÖŒºŒ≤·øÜŒΩŒ±Œπ ·ºÄŒº·ΩµœáŒ±ŒΩŒøŒΩ. So Victor of Antioch, in his Catena on S. Mark (ed. Possin.) He makes the remark twice: first (p. 351) in the midst of an abridgment of the beginning of Chrysostom's 88th Homily on S. Matthew: next (p. 352) more fully, after quoting ‚Äúthe great Dionysius‚Äù of Alexandria. See also an interesting passage on the same subject in Cramer's Catena in Matth. i. p. 237,‚Äîfrom whom derived, I know not; but professing to be from Chrysostom. (Note, that the 10 lines ·ºêŒæ ·ºÄŒΩŒµœÄŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒøœÖ, beginning p. 236, line 33 = Chrys. vii. 824, D, E.) The very next words in Chrysostom's published Homily (p. 825 A.) are as follows:‚Äî·ΩçœÑŒµ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ Œø·ΩêŒ∫ ·º¶ŒΩ ·ºîŒ∫ŒªŒµŒπœàŒπœÇ, Œ±ŒªŒª·æΩ ·ΩÄœÅŒ≥·Ωµ œÑŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒ≥Œ±ŒΩ·Ω±Œ∫œÑŒ∑œÉŒπœÇ, Œø·ΩêŒ∫ ·ºêŒΩœÑŒµ·ø¶Œ∏ŒµŒΩ Œº·ΩπŒΩŒøŒΩ Œ¥·øÜŒªŒøŒΩ ·º¶ŒΩ, ·ºÄŒªŒª·Ω∞ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄœÄ·Ω∏ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ∫Œ±ŒπœÅŒø·ø¶; œÑœÅŒµ·øñœÇ Œ≥·ºÄœÅ ·Ω•œÅŒ±œÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω≥ŒºŒµŒπŒΩŒµŒΩ, ·º° Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºîŒ∫ŒªŒµŒπœàŒπœÇ ·ºêŒΩ ŒºŒπ·æ∑ Œ≥·Ω∑ŒΩŒµœÑŒ±Œπ Œ∫Œ±ŒπœÅŒø·ø¶ ·ø•ŒøœÄ·øá.‚ÄîAnyone who would investigate this matter further should by all means read Matthaei's long note on S. Luke xxiii. 45.

153.
‚ÄúEpistola quam nos ‚Äòad Ephesios‚Äô pr√¶scriptam habemus, h√¶retici vero 'ad Laodicenos.‚Äù Adv. Marcion. lib. v. c. xi, p. 309 (ed. Oehler.)
154.
‚Äú‚Äâ‚ÄòTitulum‚Äô enim ‚Äòad Laodicenos‚Äô ut addidisse accusatur a Tertulliano, ita in salutatione verba ·ºêŒΩ ·ºòœÜ·Ω≥œÉ·ø≥ omnino non legisse censendus est.‚Äù (N. T. in loc.)
155.
‚ÄúEcclesi√¶ quidem veritate Epistolam istam ‚Äòad Ephesios‚Äô habemus emissam, non ‚Äòad Laodicenos;‚Äô sed Marcion ei titulum aliquando interpolare gestiit, quasi et in isto diligentissimus explorator.‚Äù Adv. Marcion. lib. v. c. xvii, pp. 322-3 (ed. Oehler.)
156.
·ºÄœÄ·Ω∏ ·ºêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·º∞Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ø∂ŒΩ. (Epiphan. Opp. i. 310 c.)
157.

He describes its structure minutely at vol. i. pp. 309-310, and from pp. 312-7; 318-321. [Note, by the way, the gross blunder which has crept into the printed text of Epiphanius at p. 321 d: pointed out long since by Jones, On the Canon, ii. 38.] His plan is excellent. Marcion had rejected every Gospel except S. Luke's, and of S. Paul's Epistles had retained only ten,‚Äîviz. (1st) Galatians, (2nd and 3rd) I and II Corinthians, (4th) Romans, (5th and 6th) I and II Thessalonians, (7th) Ephesians, (8th) Colossians, (9th) Philemon, (10th) Philippians. Even these he had mutilated and depraved. And yet out of that one mutilated Gospel, Epiphanius selects 78 passages, (pp. 312-7), and out of those ten mutilated Epistles, 40 passages more (pp. 318-21); by means of which 118 texts he undertakes to refute the heresy of Marcion. (pp. 322-50: 350-74.) [It will be perceived that Tertullian goes over Marcion's work in much the same way.] Very beautiful, and well worthy of the student's attention, (though it comes before us in a somewhat incorrect form,) is the remark of Epiphanius concerning the living energy of God's Word, even when dismembered and exhibited in a fragmentary shape. ‚Äú·ΩçŒªŒøœÖ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉ·ΩΩŒºŒ±œÑŒøœÇ Œ∂·ø∂ŒΩœÑŒøœÇ, ·Ω°œÇ Œµ·º∞œÄŒµ·øñŒΩ, œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ∏Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ Œ≥œÅŒ±œÜ·øÜœÇ, œÄŒø·øñŒøŒΩ Œ∑·ΩïœÅŒπœÉŒ∫Œµ (sc. Marcion) Œº·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ ŒΩŒµŒ∫œÅ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑŒø·ø¶ Œ≥ŒΩ·ΩΩŒºŒ∑ŒΩ, ·ºµŒΩŒ± œÄŒ±œÅŒµŒπœÉŒ±Œ≥·Ω±Œ≥Œ∑ œàŒµ·ø¶Œ¥ŒøœÇ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒªŒ∑Œ∏Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ; ... œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω≥Œ∫ŒøœàŒµ œÄŒøŒªŒª·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºŒµŒª·ø∂ŒΩ, Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω≥œÉœáŒµ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºîŒΩŒπ·Ω± œÑŒπŒΩŒ± œÄŒ±œÅ·æΩ ·ºëŒ±œÖœÑ·ø∑; Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∞ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·Ω∞ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±œÉœáŒµŒ∏·Ω≥ŒΩœÑŒ± ·ºîœÑŒπ Œ∂·ø∂ŒΩœÑŒ± Œø·Ωê Œ¥·ΩªŒΩŒ±œÑŒ±Œπ ŒΩŒµŒ∫œÅŒø·ø¶œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ, ·ºÄŒªŒª·æΩ ·ºêŒ∫Œµ·øñ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∂œâœÑŒπŒ∫·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºêŒºœÜ·Ω±œÉŒµœâœÇ, Œ∫·æ¥ŒΩ œÑŒµ ŒºœÖœÅ·Ω∑œâœÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·æΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∑ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒªŒµœÄœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÑŒºŒ∑Œ∏Œµ·Ω∑ŒΩ.‚Äù (p. 375 b.) He seems to say of Marcion,‚Äî

Fool! to suppose thy shallow wits
Could quench a fire like that. Go, learn
That cut into ten thousand bits
Yet every bit would breathe and burn!

He quotes Ephes. ii. 11, 12, 13, 14: v. 14: v. 31. (See Epiphanius, Opp. i. p. 318 and 371-2.)
159.
Ibid. p. 318 c ( = 371 b), and 319 a ( = 374 a.)
160.
Ibid. p. 319 and 374. But note, that through error in the copies, or else through inadvertence in the Editor, the depravation commented on at p. 374 b, c, is lost sight of at p. 319 b.

162.

Œ†œÅŒøœÉ·Ω≥Œ∏ŒµœÑŒø Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ ·º∞Œ¥·Ω∑·ø≥ ·ºàœÄŒøœÉœÑŒøŒªŒπŒ∫·ø∑ Œ∫Œ±ŒªŒøœÖŒº·Ω≥ŒΩ·ø≥ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ∫Œ±ŒªŒøœÖŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒ∑œÇ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ŒõŒ±ŒøŒ¥ŒπŒ∫·Ω≥Œ±œÇ:‚Äî‚ÄúŒï·øñœÇ Œö·ΩªœÅŒπŒøœÇ, Œº·Ω∑Œ± œÄ·Ω∑œÉœÑŒπœÇ, ·ºïŒΩ Œ≤·Ω±œÄœÑŒπœÉŒºŒ±, Œµ·º∂œÇ ŒßœÅŒπœÉœÑ·Ω∏œÇ, Œµ·º∂œÇ ŒòŒµ·Ω∏œÇ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ†Œ±œÑ·Ω¥œÅ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ, ·ΩÅ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ¥Œπ·Ω∞ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºêŒΩ œÄ·æ∂œÉŒπŒΩ.‚Äù (Epiphan. Opp. vol i. p. 374.) Here is obviously a hint of œÑœÅŒπ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±œÅœáœâŒΩ ·ºÄœÅœá·ø∂ŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÜŒøœÅ·Ω∞œÇ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ·ºÄŒªŒª·ΩµŒªŒ±œÇ ·ºêŒæŒøœÖœÉ·ø∂ŒΩ: [ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫·Ω∑œâŒΩŒøœÇ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒºŒ±œÑŒ±Œπ·ΩπœÜœÅŒøŒΩŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω∑Œ¥Œ±Œ≥ŒºŒ±, Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑœÅŒµ·øñœÇ ·ºÄœÅœá·Ω∞œÇ œÑ·øÜœÇ ŒºŒøŒΩŒ±œÅœá·Ω∑Œ±œÇ œÑŒøŒº·Ω¥ŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ¥ŒπŒ±·Ω∑œÅŒµœÉŒπŒΩ. Athanas. i. 231 e.] but, (says Epiphanius), Œø·Ωêœá Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ ·ºîœáŒµŒπ ·º° œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑ŒøœÖ ·ºàœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒªŒøœÖ ·ΩëœÄ·ΩπŒ∏ŒµœÉŒπœÇ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·º†œÉœÜŒ±ŒªŒπœÉŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒΩ Œ∫·ΩµœÅœÖŒ≥ŒºŒ±. ·ºÄŒªŒª·Ω∞ ·ºÑŒªŒªœâœÇ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ œÉ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÄŒøŒπ·ΩµœÑŒµœÖŒºŒ±. Then he contrasts with the ‚Äúfabrication‚Äù of Marcion, the inspired verity,‚ÄîEph. iv. 5: declaring ·ºïŒΩŒ± ŒòŒµ·Ω∏ŒΩ, œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÄŒ±œÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ± œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ,‚ÄîœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºêŒΩ œÄ·æ∂œÉŒπ, Œ∫.œÑ.Œª.‚Äîp. 374 c.

Epiphanius reproaches Marcion with having obtained materials ·ºêŒ∫œÑ·Ω∏œÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œï·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ºàœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒªŒøœÖ; Œø·Ωê Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºîŒ¥ŒøŒæŒµ œÑ·ø∑ ·ºêŒªŒµŒµŒπŒΩŒøœÑ·Ω±œÑ·ø≥ ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫·Ω∑œâŒΩŒπ ·ºÄœÄ·Ω∏ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ·ºòœÜŒµœÉ·Ω∑ŒøœÖœÇ œÑŒ±·ΩªœÑŒ∑ŒΩ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµŒπŒΩ, (sc. the words quoted above,) ·ºÄŒªŒª·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ŒõŒ±ŒøŒ¥ŒπŒ∫·Ω≥Œ±œÇ, œÑ·øÜœÇ Œº·Ω¥ Œø·ΩîœÉŒ∑œÇ ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ ·ºàœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒª·ø≥ (p. 375 a.) (Epiphanius here uses ·ºàœÄ·ΩπœÉœÑŒøŒªŒøœÇ in its technical sense,‚Äîviz. as synonymous with S. Paul's Epistles.)

163.
‚Äú·Ω®œÅŒπŒ≥·Ω≥ŒΩŒ∑œÇ Œ¥·Ω≥ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπ,‚Äî‚Äù·ºòœÄ·Ω∂ Œº·ΩπŒΩœâŒΩ ·ºòœÜŒµœÉ·Ω∑œâŒΩ Œµ·ΩïœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩ Œ∫Œµ·Ω∑ŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ ‚ÄúœÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑ŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œø·ΩñœÉŒπ;‚Äù Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ∂Œ∑œÑŒø·ø¶ŒºŒµŒΩ, Œµ·º∞ Œº·Ω¥ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω≥ŒªŒ∫ŒµŒπ œÄœÅŒøœÉŒ∫Œµ·Ω∑ŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ ‚ÄúœÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑ŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œø·ΩñœÉŒπ,‚Äù œÑ·Ω∑ Œ¥·ΩªŒΩŒ±œÑŒ±Œπ œÉŒ∑ŒºŒ±·Ω∑ŒΩŒµŒπŒΩ; ·ΩÖœÅŒ± Œø·ΩñŒΩ Œµ·º∞ Œº·Ω¥ ·Ω•œÉœÄŒµœÅ ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·øá ·ºòŒæ·ΩπŒ¥œâ ·ΩÑŒΩŒøŒº·Ω± œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ ·ºëŒ±œÖœÑŒø·ø¶ ·ΩÅ œáœÅŒ∑ŒºŒ±œÑ·Ω∑Œ∂œâŒΩ ŒúœâœÉŒµ·Ω∑ œÑ·Ω∏ ·Ω¨Œù Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ Œø·º± ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω≥œáŒøŒΩœÑŒµœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ΩÑŒΩœÑŒøœÇ Œ≥·Ω∑ŒΩŒøŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ ‚Äú·ΩÑŒΩœÑŒµœÇ.‚Äù Œ∫Œ±ŒªŒø·ΩªŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒπ Œø·º±ŒøŒΩŒµ·Ω∂ ·ºêŒ∫ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œº·Ω¥ Œµ·º∂œÇ Œ±Œπ Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ. ‚Äú·ºêŒæŒµŒª·Ω≥ŒæŒ±œÑŒø Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ΩÅ ŒòŒµ·Ω∏œÇ œÑ·Ω∞ Œº·Ω¥ ·ΩÑŒΩœÑŒ±,‚Äù œÜŒ∑œÉ·Ω∂ŒΩ ·ΩÅ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏œÇ Œ†Œ±·ø¶ŒªŒøœÇ, ‚Äú·ºµŒΩŒ± œÑ·Ω∞ ·ΩÑŒΩœÑŒ± Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±œÅŒ≥·ΩµœÉŒ∑.‚Äù‚ÄîCramer's Catena in Ephes. i. 1,‚Äîvol. vi. p. 102.

‚ÄúQuidam curiosius quam necesse est putant ex eo quod Moysi dictum est ‚ÄòHaec dices filiis Israel, Qui est misit me,‚Äô etiam eos qui Ephesi sunt [Note this. Cf. ‚Äòqui sunt Ephesi,‚Äô Vulg.] sancti et fideles, essentiae vocabulo nuncupatos: ut ... ab Eo ‚Äòqui est,‚Äô hi ‚Äòqui sunt‚Äô appellentur.... Alii veto simpliciter, non ad eos ‚Äòqui sint,‚Äô sed ‚Äòqui Ephesi sancti et fideles sint‚Äô scriptum arbitrantur.‚Äù Hieron. Opp. vii. p. 545 a, b.
169.
The cursive ‚ÄúCod. No. 67‚Äù (or ‚Äú672‚Äù) is improperly quoted as ‚Äúomitting‚Äù (Tisch.) these words. The reference is to a MS. in the Imperial Library at Vienna, (Nessel 302: Lambec. 34, which = our Paul 67), collated by Alter (N.T. 1786, vol. ii. pp. 415-558), who says of it (p. 496),‚Äî‚Äúcod. ·ºêŒΩ ·ºòœÜ·Ω≥œÉ·ø≥ punctis notat.‚Äù ... The MS. must have a curious history. H. Treschow describes it in his Tentamen Descriptionis Codd. aliquot Graece, &c. Havn. 1773, pp. 62-73.‚ÄîAlso, A. C. Hwiid in his Libellus Criticus de indole Cod. MS. Graeci N. T. Lambec. xxxiv. &c. Havn. 1785.‚ÄîIt appears to have been corrected by some Critic,‚Äîperhaps from Cod. B itself.

178.

Let it be clearly understood by the advocates of this expedient for accounting for the state of the text of Codd. B. and ◊ê, that nothing whatever is gained for the credit of those two MSS. by their ingenuity. Even if we grant them all they ask, the Codices in question remain, by their own admission, defective.

Quite plain is it, by the very hypothesis, that one of two courses alone remains open to them in editing the text: either (1) To leave a blank space after œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œø·ΩîœÉŒπŒΩ: or else, (2) To let the words ·ºêŒΩ ·ºòœÜ·Ω≥œÉ·ø≥ stand,‚Äîwhich I respectfully suggest is the wisest thing they can do. [For with Conybeare and Howson (Life and Letters of S. Paul, ii. 491), to eject the words ‚Äúat Ephesus‚Äù from the text of Ephes. i. 1, and actually to substitute in their room the words ‚Äúin Laodicea,‚Äù‚Äîis plainly abhorrent to every principle of rational criticism. The remarks of C. and H. on this subject (pp. 486 ff) have been faithfully met and sufficiently disposed of by Dean Alford (vol. iii. Prolegg. pp. 13-8); who infers, ‚Äúin accordance with the prevalent belief of the Church in all ages, that this Epistle was veritably addressed to the Saints in Ephesus, and to no other Church.‚Äù] In the former case, they will be exhibiting a curiosity; viz. they will be shewing us how (they think) a duplicate (‚Äúcarta bianca‚Äù) copy of the Epistle looked with ‚Äúthe space after œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œø·ΩîœÉŒπ left utterly void:‚Äù in the latter, they will be representing the archetypal copy which was sent to the Metropolitan see of Ephesus. But by printing the text thus,‚ÄîœÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑ŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œø·ΩîœÉŒπŒΩ [·ºêŒΩ ·ºòœÜ·Ω≥œÉœâ] Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÄŒπœÉœÑŒø·øñœÇ Œ∫.œÑ.Œª., they are acting on an entirely different theory. They are merely testifying their mistrust of the text of every MS. in the world except Codd. B and ◊ê. This is clearly to forsake the ‚ÄúEncyclical‚Äù hypothesis altogether, and to put Ephes. i. 1 on the same footing as any other disputed text of Scripture which can be named.

179.
·ºòŒ≥Œ∫·ΩªŒ∫ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ ·ºêœÄŒπœÉœÑŒøŒª·ΩµŒΩ, vel ·ºêŒ≥Œ∫·ΩªŒ∫ŒªŒπŒ± Œ≥œÅ·Ω±ŒºŒºŒ±œÑŒ± Christophorsonus et alii interpretantur literas circulares: ego cum viris doctis malim Epistolas vel literas publicas, ad omnes fideles pertinentes, quas Gr√¶ci ali√†s vocant ·ºêœÄŒπœÉœÑŒøŒª·Ω∞œÇ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏ŒøŒªŒπŒ∫·Ω±œÇ.‚ÄîSuicer in voce.
180.
ŒöŒ±Œ∏ŒøŒªŒπŒ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒøŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ Œ±·ΩïœÑŒ±Œπ, Œø·º∞ŒøŒΩŒµ·Ω∂ ·ºêŒ≥Œ∫·ΩªŒ∫ŒªŒπŒøŒπ‚ÄîSee Suicer in voce, ·ºòŒ≥Œ∫·ΩªŒ∫ŒªŒπŒøœÇ.
181.
Routh's Reliqui√¶, vol. iii. p. 266.‚Äî‚ÄúTum ex Conciliis, tum ex aliis Patrum scriptis notum est, consuevisse primos Ecclesiao Patres acta et decreta Conciliorum passim ad omnes Dei Ecclesias mittere per epistolas, quas non uni privatim dic√¢runt, sed publice describi ab omnibus, dividi passim et pervulgari, atque cum omnibus populis communicari voluerunt. Hac igitur epistolae ·ºêŒ≥Œ∫·ΩªŒ∫ŒªŒπŒøŒπ vocatae sunt, quia Œ∫œÖŒ∫Œª·ΩπœÉŒµ, quoqu√≤ versum et in omnem partem mittebantur.‚Äù‚ÄîSuicer in voc.
182.

‚ÄúOn the whole,‚Äù says Bishop Middleton, (Doctrine of the Greek Art. p. 355) ‚ÄúI see nothing so probable as the opinion of Macknight (on Col. iv. 16,)‚Äî‚Äòthat the Apostle sent the Ephesians word by Tychicus, who carried their letter, to send a copy of it to the Laodiceans; with an order to them to communicate it to the Colossians.‚Äô‚Äâ‚Äù‚ÄîThis suggestion is intended to meet another difficulty, and leaves the question of the reading of Ephes. i. 1 untouched. It proposes only to explain what S. Paul means by the enigmatical expression which is found in Col. iv. 16.

Macknight's suggestion, though it has found favour with many subsequent Divines, appears to me improbable in a high degree. S. Paul is found not to have sent the Colossians ‚Äúword by Tychicus, who carried their letter, to send a copy of it to the Laodiceans.‚Äù He charged them, himself, to do so. Why, at the same instant, is the Apostle to be thought to have adopted two such different methods of achieving one and the same important end? And why, instead of this roundabout method of communication, were not the Ephesians ordered,‚Äîif not by S. Paul himself, at least by Tychicus,‚Äîto send a copy of their Epistle to Colosse direct? And why do we find the Colossians charged to read publicly œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºêŒ∫ ŒõŒ±ŒøŒ¥ŒπŒ∫Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ, which (by the hypothesis) would have been only a copy,‚Äîinstead of œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºêŒæ ·ºòœÜ·Ω≥œÉŒøœÖ, which, (by the same hypothesis,) would have been the original? Nay, why is it not designated by S. Paul, œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ·ºòœÜŒµœÉ·Ω∑ŒøœÖœÇ,‚Äî(if indeed it was his Epistle to the Ephesians which is alluded to,) instead of œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºêŒ∫ ŒõŒ±ŒøŒ¥ŒπŒ∫Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ; which would hardly be an intelligible way of indicating the document? Lastly, why are not the Colossians ordered to communicate a copy of their Epistle to the illustrious Church of the Ephesians also, which had been originally addressed by S. Paul? If the Colossians must needs read the Epistle (so like their own) which the Apostle had just written to the Ephesians, surely the Ephesians must also be supposed to have required a sight of the Epistle which S. Paul had at the same time written to the Colossians!

183.
Epiphan. Opp. i. 311 D.
184.
‚ÄúMarcion exerte et palam mach√¶ra non stilo usus est, quoniam ad materiam suam c√¶dem Scripturarum confecit.‚Äù (Tertullian Pr√¶script. H√¶r. c. 38, p. 50.) ‚ÄúNon miror si syllabas subtrahit, cum paginas totas plerumque subducat.‚Äù (Adv. Marcion. lib. v, c. xvii, p. 455.)

187.

188.

One is rather surprised to find the facts of the case so unfairly represented in addressing unlearned readers; who are entitled to the largest amount of ingenuousness, and to entire sincerity of statement. The facts are these:‚Äî

(1) Valentt. (apud Iren√¶um), (2) Clemens Alex., and (3) Theodotus (apud Clem.) read ·ºîœÉœÑŒπ: but then (1) Iren√¶us himself, (2) Clemens Alex., and (3) Theodotus (apud Clem.) also read ·º¶ŒΩ. These testimonies, therefore, clearly neutralize each other. Cyprian also has both readings.‚ÄîHippolytus, on the other hand, reads ·ºîœÉœÑŒπ; but Origen, (though he remarks that ·ºîœÉœÑŒπ is ‚Äúperhaps not an improbable reading,‚Äù) reads ·º¶ŒΩ ten or eleven times. ·ºÆŒΩ is also the reading of Eusebius, of Chrysostom, of Cyril, of Nonnus, of Theodoret,‚Äîof the Vulgate, of the Memphitic, of the Peshito, and of the Philoxenian Versions; as well as of B, A, C,‚Äîin fact of all the MSS. in the world, except of ◊ê and D.

All that remains to be set on the other side are the Thebaic and Cureton's Syriac, together with most copies of the early Latin.

And now, with the evidence thus all before us, will any one say that it is lawfully a question for discussion which of these two readings must exhibit the genuine text of S. John i. 4? (For I treat it as a question of authority, and reason from the evidence,‚Äîdeclining to import into the argument what may be called logical considerations; though I conceive them to be all on my side.) I suspect, in fact, that the inveterate practice of the primitive age of reading the place after the following strange fashion,‚Äî·ΩÅ Œ≥·Ω≥Œ≥ŒøŒΩŒµŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∑ Œ∂œâ·Ω¥ ·º¶ŒΩ, was what led to this depravation of the text. Cyril in his Commentary [heading of lib. i, c. vi.] so reads S. John i. 3, 4. And to substitute ·ºêœÉœÑ·Ω∑ (for ·º¶ŒΩ) in such a sentence as that, was obvious.... Chrysostom's opinion is well known, ‚ÄúLet us beware of putting the full stop‚Äù (he says) ‚Äúat the words Œø·ΩêŒ¥·Ω≤ ·ºêŒΩ,‚Äîas do the heretics.‚Äù [He alludes to Valentinus, Heracleon (Orig. Opp. i. 130), and to Theodotus (apud Clem. Alex.). But it must be confessed that Iren√¶us, Hippolytus (Routh, Opusc. i. 68), Clemens Alex., Origen, Concil. Antioch. (A.D. 269, Routh iii. 293), Theophilus Antioch., Athanasius, Cyril of Jer.,‚Äîbesides of the Latins, Tertullian, Lactantius, Victorinus (Routh iii. 459), and Augustine,‚Äîpoint the place in the same way. ‚ÄúIt is worth our observation,‚Äù (says Pearson,) ‚Äúthat Eusebius citing the place of S. John to prove that the Holy Ghost was made by the Son, leaves out those words twice together by which the Catholics used to refute that heresy of the Arians, viz. ·ΩÅ Œ≥·Ω≥Œ≥ŒøŒΩŒµŒΩ.‚Äù]

Chrysostom proceeds,‚Äî‚ÄúIn order to make out that the Spirit is a creature, they read ·Ωâ Œ≥·Ω≥Œ≥ŒøŒΩŒµ, ·ºêŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø≥ Œ∂œâ·Ω¥ ·º¶ŒΩ; by which means, the Evangelist's language is made unintelligible.‚Äù (Opp. viii. 40.)‚ÄîThis punctuation is nevertheless adopted by Tregelles,‚Äîbut not by Tischendorf. The Peshito, Epiphanius (quoted in Pearson's note, referred to infr√†), Cyprian, Jerome and the Vulgate divide the sentence as we do.‚ÄîSee by all means on this subject Pearson's note (z), Art. viii, (ii. p. 262 ed. Burton). Also Routh's Opusc. i. 88-9.

189.

It may not be altogether useless that I should follow this famous Critic of the text of the N. T. over the ground which he has himself chosen. He challenges attention for the four following readings of the Codex Sinaiticus:‚Äî

(1.) S. John i. 4: ŒµŒΩ Œ±œÖœÑœâ Œ∂œâŒ∑ ŒµœÉœÑŒπŒΩ.‚Äî(2.) S. Matth. xiii. 35: œÑŒø œÅŒ∑Œ∏ŒµŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ± Œ∑œÉŒ±ŒπŒøœÖ œÑŒøœÖ œÄœÅŒøœÜŒµœÑŒøœÖ.‚Äî(3.) S. John xiii. 10: Œø ŒªŒµŒªŒøœÖŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ŒøœÖœá ŒµœáŒπ œáœÅŒµŒπŒ±ŒΩ ŒΩŒπœàŒ±œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ.‚Äî(4.) S. John vi. 51: Œ±ŒΩ œÑŒπœÇ œÜŒ±Œ≥Œ∑ ŒµŒ∫ œÑŒøœÖ ŒµŒºŒøœÖ Œ±œÅœÖŒøœÖ, Œ∂Œ∑œÉŒµŒπ ŒµŒπœÇ œÑŒøŒΩ Œ±ŒπœâŒΩŒ±;‚ÄîŒø Œ±œÅœÑŒøœÇ ŒøŒΩ ŒµŒ≥œâ Œ¥œâœÉœâ œÖœÄŒµœÅ œÑŒ∑œÇ œÑŒøœÖ Œ∫ŒøœÉŒºŒøœÖ Œ∂œâŒ∑œÇ Œ∑ œÉŒ±œÅŒæ ŒºŒøœÖ ŒµœÉœÑŒπŒΩ. (And this, Dr. Teschendorf asserts to be ‚Äúindubitably correct.‚Äù)

On inspection, these four readings prove to be exactly what might have been anticipated from the announcement that they are almost the private property of the single Codex ◊ê. The last three are absolutely worthless. They stand self-condemned. To examine is to reject them: the second (of which Jerome says something very different from what Tisch. pretends) and fourth being only two more of those unskilful attempts at critical emendation of the inspired Text, of which this Codex contains so many sorry specimens: the third being clearly nothing else but the result of the carelessness of the transcriber. Misled by the like ending (·ΩÅŒºŒøŒπŒøœÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒµœÖœÑŒøŒΩ) he has dropped a line: thus:‚Äî

ŒüŒ•Œß ŒïŒßŒô ŒßŒ°ŒïŒôŒëŒù [ŒïŒô
ŒúŒó Œ§ŒüŒ•Œ£ Œ†ŒüŒîŒëŒ£] ŒùŒô
Œ®ŒëŒ£ŒòŒëŒô ŒëŒõŒõŒë ŒïŒ£Œ§ŒôŒù

The first, I have discussed briefly in the foregoing footnote (p) p. 110.

199.
In Cod. 264 (= Paris 65) for instance, besides at S. Mk. xvi. 9, + occurs at xi. 12, xii. 38, and xiv. 12. On the other hand, no such sign occurs at the pericope de adulter√°.
200.

201.
Similarly, in Cod. Coisl. 20, in the Paris Library, (which = our 36,) against S. Mark xvi. 9, is this sign [symbol: inverse or open x]. It is intended (like an asterisk in a modern book) to refer the reader to the self-same annotation which is spoken of in the text as occurring in Cod. Vat. 756, and which is observed to occur in the margin of the Paris MS. also.

204.

At the end of S. Matthew's Gospel in Cod. 300 (at fol. 89) is found,‚Äî

Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ ·ºêŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒ∑ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒµŒ≤Œª·ΩµŒ∏Œ∑ ·ºêŒ∫ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºπŒµœÅŒøœÉŒøŒª·ΩªŒºŒøŒπœÇ œÄŒ±ŒªŒ±Œπ·ΩºŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ, ·ºêŒΩ œÉœÑ·Ω∑œáŒøŒπœÇ Œ≤œÜŒπŒ¥

and at the end of S. Mark's, (at fol. 147 b)‚Äî

Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ ·ºêŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒ∑ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒµŒ≤Œª·ΩµŒ∏Œ∑ ·ΩÅŒºŒø·Ω∑œâœÇ ·ºêŒ∫ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºêœÉœÄŒøœÖŒ¥Œ±œÉŒº·Ω≥ŒΩœâŒΩ œÉœÑ·Ω∑œáŒøŒπœÇ Œ±œÜœÇ Œ∫ŒµœÜŒ±ŒªŒ±·Ω∑ŒøŒπœÇ œÉŒªŒæ

This second colophon (though not the first) is found in Cod. 20. Both reappear in Cod. 262 ( = Paris 53), and (with an interesting variety in the former of the two) in [what I suppose is the first half of] the uncial Codex Œõ. See Scrivener's Introduction, p. 125.

207.

·ºîŒΩ œÑŒπœÉŒπ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ ·ºïœâœÇ ·ΩßŒ¥Œµ œÄŒªŒ∑œÅŒø·ø¶œÑŒ±Œπ ·ΩÅ Œï·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπœÉœÑ·Ω¥œÇ, ·ºïœâœÇ Œø·º± Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºòœÖœÉ·Ω≥Œ≤ŒπŒøœÇ ·ΩÅ Œ†Œ±ŒºœÜ·Ω∑ŒªŒøœÖ ·ºêŒ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ΩπŒΩŒπœÉŒµŒΩ; ·ºêŒΩ ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøŒπœÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑŒ±·ø¶œÑŒ± œÜ·Ω≥œÅŒµœÑŒ±Œπ; ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ, Œ∫.œÑ.Œª.

·ºîŒΩ œÑŒπœÉŒπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ Œø·Ωê Œ∫Œµ·øñŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ [?] œÑŒ±·ø¶œÑŒ±.

218.
As, the Codex Bobbiensis (k) of the old Latin, and the margin of two √Üthiopic MSS.‚ÄîI am unable to understand what Scholz and his copyists have said concerning Cod. 274. I was assured again and again at Paris that they knew of no such codex as ‚ÄúReg, 79a,‚Äù which is Scholz' designation (Prolegg. p. lxxx.) of the Cod. Evan. which, after him, we number ‚Äú274.‚Äù

221.
The reader is invited to test the accuracy of what precedes for himself:‚Äî·ºàŒºŒº·ΩΩŒΩŒπŒøœÇ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ ·ΩÅ ·ºàŒªŒµŒæŒ±ŒΩŒ¥œÅŒµ·Ω∫œÇ, œÄŒøŒªŒª·Ω¥ŒΩ, ·Ω°œÇ Œµ·º∞Œ∫·Ω∏œÇ, œÜŒπŒªŒøœÄŒøŒΩ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÉœÄŒøœÖŒ¥·Ω¥ŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÉŒ±Œ≥Œ∑Œøœá·ΩºœÇ, œÑ·Ω∏ Œ¥Œπ·Ω∞ œÑŒµœÉœÉ·Ω±œÅœâŒΩ ·º°Œº·øñŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±Œª·Ω≥ŒªŒøŒπœÄŒµŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ, œÑ·ø∑ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøŒΩ œÑ·Ω∞œÇ ·ΩÅŒºŒøœÜ·ΩΩŒΩŒøœÖœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒªŒøŒπœÄ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπœÉœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ∫ŒøœÄ·Ω∞œÇ œÄŒ±œÅŒ±Œ∏Œµ·Ω∂œÇ, ·Ω•œÇ ·ºêŒæ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±Œ≥Œ∫Œ∑œÇ œÉœÖŒºŒ≤·øÜŒΩŒ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ±œÇ Œµ·º±œÅŒº·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÑœÅŒπ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÜŒ∏Œ±œÅ·øÜŒΩŒ±Œπ, ·ΩÖœÉŒøŒΩ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·ø∑ ·ΩÖœÜŒµŒπ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒµœâœÇ.
222.
·ºΩŒΩŒ± Œ¥·Ω≤ œÉœâŒ∂ŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒªŒøŒπœÄ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ¥Œπ·æΩ ·ΩÖŒªŒøœÖ œÉ·ΩΩŒºŒ±œÑ·ΩπœÇ œÑŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œµ·º±œÅŒºŒø·ø¶, Œµ·º∞Œ¥·Ω≥ŒΩŒ±Œπ ·ºîœáŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ Œø·º∞Œ∫Œµ·Ω∑ŒøœÖœÇ ·ºëŒ∫·Ω±œÉœÑŒøœÖ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπœÉœÑŒø·ø¶ œÑ·Ωπ œÄŒøœÖœÇ, ·ºêŒΩ Œø·º∑œÇ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·º†ŒΩ·Ω≥œáŒ∏Œ∑œÉŒ±ŒΩ œÜŒπŒªŒ±ŒªŒ∑Œ∏·ø∂œÇ Œµ·º∞œÄŒµ·øñŒΩ, ·ºêŒ∫ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÄŒøŒΩ·ΩµŒºŒ±œÑŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÄœÅŒøŒµŒπœÅŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖ ·ºÄŒΩŒ¥œÅ·Ω∏œÇ Œµ·º∞ŒªŒ∑œÜ·ΩºœÇ ·ºÄœÜŒøœÅŒº·Ω∞œÇ, Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·æΩ ·ºëœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±ŒΩ Œº·Ω≥Œ∏ŒøŒ¥ŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ΩπŒΩŒ±œÇ Œ¥·Ω≥Œ∫Œ± œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºÄœÅŒπŒ∏Œº·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒµœá·Ω±œÅŒ±Œæ·Ω± œÉŒøŒπ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÑŒµœÑŒ±Œ≥Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖœÇ.
223.
This seems to represent exactly what Eusebius means in this place. The nearest English equivalent to ·ºÄœÜŒøœÅŒº·Ωµ is ‚Äúa hint.‚Äù Consider Euseb. Hist. Eccl. v. 27. Also the following:‚ÄîœÄŒøŒªŒª·Ω∞œÇ ŒªŒ±Œ≤·ΩπŒΩœÑŒµœÇ ·ºÄœÜŒøœÅŒº·Ω±œÇ. (Andreas, Proleg. in Apocalyps.).‚ÄîŒªŒ±Œ≤·ΩπŒΩœÑŒµœÇ œÑ·Ω∞œÇ ·ºÄœÜœÅŒº·Ω±œÇ. (Anastasius Sin., Routh's Rell. i. 15.)
224.

Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ΩπŒΩŒ±œÇ ... Œ¥ŒπŒµœá·Ω±œÅŒ±Œæ·Ω± œÉŒøŒπ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÑŒµœÑŒ±Œ≥Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖœÇ. This at least is decisive as to the authorship of the Canons. When therefore Jerome says of Ammonius,‚Äî‚ÄúEvangelicos canones excogitavit quos postea secutus est Eusebius C√¶sariensis,‚Äù (De Viris Illust. c. lv. vol. ii. p. 881,) we learn the amount of attention to which such off-hand gain statements of this Father are entitled.

What else can be inferred from the account which Eusebius gives of the present sectional division of the Gospels but that it was also his own?‚ÄîŒë·ΩïœÑŒ∑ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œø·ΩñŒΩ ·º° œÑ·ΩºŒΩ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÑŒµœÑŒ±Œ≥Œº·Ω≥ŒΩœâŒΩ Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ΩπŒΩœâŒΩ ·ΩëœÄ·ΩπŒ∏ŒµœÉŒπœÇ: ·º° Œ¥·Ω≤ œÉŒ±œÜ·Ω¥œÇ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ¥Œπ·ΩµŒ≥Œ∑œÉŒπœÇ, ·ºîœÉœÑŒπŒΩ ·º§Œ¥Œµ. ·ºòœÜ·æΩ ·ºëŒ∫·Ω±œÉœÑ·ø≥ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÑŒµœÉœÉ·Ω±œÅœâŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑œâŒΩ ·ºÄœÅŒπŒ∏Œº·ΩπœÇ œÑŒπœÇ œÄœÅ·ΩπŒ∫ŒµŒπœÑŒ±Œπ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œº·Ω≥œÅŒøœÇ, ·ºÄœÅœá·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ·ºÄœÄ·Ω∏ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÄœÅ·ΩΩœÑŒøœÖ, Œµ·º∂œÑŒ± Œ¥ŒµœÖœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒøœÖ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑœÅ·Ω∑œÑŒøœÖ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏ŒµŒæ·øÜœÇ œÄœÅŒøŒπ·ΩºŒΩ Œ¥Œπ·æΩ ·ΩÖŒªŒøœÖ Œº·Ω≥œáœÅŒπ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÖœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ≤ŒπŒ≤Œª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ. He proceeds to explain how the sections thus numbered are to be referred to his X Canons:‚ÄîŒ∫Œ±Œ∏·æΩ ·ºïŒ∫Œ±œÉœÑŒøŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ºÄœÅŒπŒ∏Œº·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ΩëœÄŒøœÉŒ∑ŒºŒµ·Ω∑œâœÉŒπœÇ Œ¥Œπ·Ω∞ Œ∫ŒπŒΩŒΩŒ±Œ≤·Ω±œÅŒµœâœÇ œÄœÅ·ΩπŒ∫ŒµŒπœÑŒ±Œπ, Œ¥Œ∑ŒªŒø·ø¶œÉŒ± ·ºêŒΩ œÄŒø·Ω∑·ø≥ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≥Œ∫Œ± Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ·ΩπŒΩœâŒΩ Œ∫Œµ·Ω∑ŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ·ΩÅ ·ºÄœÅŒπŒ∏Œº·Ω∏œÇ œÑœÖŒ≥œá·Ω±ŒΩŒµŒπ.

225.

‚ÄúFrustra ad Ammonium aut Tatianum in Harmoniis provocant. Qu√¶ supersunt vix quicquam cum Ammonio aut Tatiano commune habent.‚Äù (Tischendorf on S. Mark xvi. 8).‚ÄîDr. Mill (1707),‚Äîbecause he assumed that the anonymous work which Victor of Capua brought to light in the vith century, and conjecturally assigned to Tatian, was the lost work of Ammonius, (Proleg. p. 63, ¬ß 660,)‚Äîwas of course warranted in appealing to the authority of Ammonius in support of the last twelve verses of S. Mark's Gospel. But in truth Mill's assumption cannot be maintained for a moment, as Wetstein has convincingly shewn. (Proleg. p. 68.) Any one may easily satisfy himself of the fact who will be at the pains to examine a few of the chapters with attention, bearing in mind what Eusebius has said concerning the work of Ammonius. Cap. lxxiv, for instance, contains as follows:‚ÄîMtt. xiii. 33, 34. Mk. iv. 33. Mtt. xiii. 34, 35: 10, 11. Mk. iv. 34. Mtt. xiii. 13 to 17. But here it is S. Matthew's Gospel which is dislocated,‚Äîfor verses 10, 11, and 13 to 17 of ch. xiii. come after verses 33-35; while ver. 12 has altogether disappeared.

The most convenient edition for reference is Schmeller's,‚ÄîAmmonii Alexandrini qu√¶ et Tatiani dicitur Harmonia Evangeliorum. (Vienna, 1841.)

226.
Only by the merest license of interpretation can Œµ·º∞ŒªŒ∑œÜ·ΩºœÇ ·ºÄœÜŒøœÅŒº·Ω±œÇ be assumed to mean that Eusebius had found the four Gospels ready divided to his hand by Ammonius into exactly 1165 sections,‚Äîevery one of which he had simply adopted for his own. Mill, (who nevertheless held this strange opinion,) was obliged to invent the wild hypothesis that Eusebius, besides the work of Ammonius which he describes, must have found in the library at C√¶sarea the private copy of the Gospels which belonged to Ammonius,‚Äîan unique volume, in which the last-named Father (as he assumes) will have numbered the Sections and made them exactly 1165. It is not necessary to discuss such a notion. We are dealing with facts,‚Äînot with fictions.
227.

230.

[= ver. 9] œÑŒ±·ΩªœÑŒ∑ŒΩ Œï·ΩêœÉ·Ω≥Œ≤ŒπŒøœÇ ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ ŒúŒ±œÅ·øñŒΩŒøŒΩ ·ºëœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±ŒΩ Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµŒπ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÄŒ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ Œ∏ŒµŒ±œÉŒ±Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒ∑ŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ŒΩŒµŒ±ŒΩ·Ω∑œÉŒ∫ŒøŒΩ. ·º• Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒºœÜ·ΩπœÑŒµœÅŒ±Œπ ·ºêŒ∫ œÑ·øÜœÇ ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øÜœÇ ·º¢œÉŒ±ŒΩ. ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑŒ±·ø¶œÑŒ± Œ¥œÖœÉ·Ω∂ŒΩ ·ºêŒæ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπœÄŒ±œÑŒø·ø¶œÉŒπ. Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºëŒæ·øÜœÇ [= ver. 12.] œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ ·ºÄŒºœÜ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ŒöŒª·Ω≥ŒøœÄŒ±ŒΩ, Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·ΩºœÇ ·ΩÅ ŒõŒøœÖŒ∫·æ∂œÇ ·º±œÉœÑŒøœÅŒµ·øñ, (Possini sini Cat. p. 364):‚ÄîWhere it will be seen that Text (Œ∫Œµ·Ω∑ŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒΩ) and Interpretation (·ºëœÅŒºŒ∑ŒΩŒµ·Ω∑Œ±) are confusedly thrown together. ‚ÄúAnonymus [Vaticanus]‚Äù also quotes S. Mark xvi. 9 at p. 109, ad fin.‚ÄîMatthaei (N.T. ii. 269),‚Äîoverlooking the fact that ‚ÄúAnonymus Vaticanus‚Äù (or simply ‚ÄúAnonymus‚Äù) and ‚ÄúAnonymus Tolosanus‚Äù (or simply ‚ÄúTolosanus‚Äù) denote two distinct Codices,‚Äîfalls into a mistake himself while contradicting our learned countryman Mill, who says,‚Äî‚ÄúCerte Victor Antioch. ac Anonymus Tolosanues huc usque [sc. ver. 8] nec ultra commentantur.‚Äù‚ÄîScholz' dictum is,‚Äî‚ÄúCommentatorum qui in catenis SS. Petrum ad Marcum laudantur, nulla explicatio hujus pericop√¶ exhibetur.‚Äù

·ºÄŒºœÜŒø·øñŒΩ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ΩÑŒΩœÑœâŒΩ œÜ·Ω∑ŒªŒøŒπŒΩ, ·ΩÖœÉŒπŒøŒΩ œÄœÅŒøœÑŒπŒº·æ∂ŒΩ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºÄŒª·ΩµŒ∏ŒµŒπŒ±ŒΩ.‚ÄîArist. Eth. Nic. I. iii.
245.
To the honour of the Rev. F. H. Scrivener be it said, that he at least absolutely refuses to pay any attention at all ‚Äúto the argument against these twelve verses arising from their alleged difference in style from the rest of the Gospel.‚Äù See by all means his remarks on this subject. (Introduction, pp. 431-2.)‚ÄîOne would have thought that a recent controversy concerning a short English Poem,‚Äîwhich some able men were confident might have been written by Milton, while others were just as confident that it could not possibly be his,‚Äîought to have opened the eyes of all to the precarious nature of such Criticism.
246.

Allusion is made to the Rev. John A. Broadus, D.D.,‚Äî‚ÄúProfessor of Interpretation of the New Testament in the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, Greenville, S.C.,‚Äù‚Äîthe author of an able and convincing paper entitled ‚ÄúExegetical Studies‚Äù in ‚ÄúThe Baptist Quarterly‚Äù for July, 1869 (Philadelphia), pp. 355-62: in which ‚Äúthe words and phrases‚Äù contained in S. Mark xvi. 9-20 are exclusively examined.

If the present volume should ever reach the learned Professor's hands, he will perceive that I must have written the present Chapter before I knew of his labours: (an advantage which I owe to Mr. Scrivener's kindness:) my treatment of the subject and his own being so entirely different. But it is only due to Professor Broadus to acknowledge the interest and advantage with which I have compared my lucubrations with his, and the sincere satisfaction with which I have discovered that we have everywhere independently arrived at precisely the same result.

247.
Dr. Kay's Crisis Hupfeldiana, p. 34,‚Äîthe most masterly and instructive exposure of Bp. Colenso's incompetence and presumption which has ever appeared. Intended specially of his handling of the writings of Moses, the remarks in the text are equally applicable to much which has been put forth concerning the authorship of the end of S. Mark's Gospel.

252.
And yet, if it were ever so ‚Äúsententious,‚Äù ever so ‚Äúabrupt;‚Äù and if his ‚Äúbrief notices‚Äù were over so ‚Äúloosely linked together;‚Äù‚Äîthese, according to Dr. Davidson, would only be indications that S. Mark actually was their Author. Hear him discussing S. Mark's ‚Äúcharacteristics,‚Äù at p. 151:‚Äî‚ÄúIn the consecution of his narrations, Mark puts them together very loosely.‚Äù ‚ÄúMark is also characterised by a conciseness and apparent incompleteness of delineation which are allied to the obscure.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe abrupt introduction‚Äù of many of his details is again and again appealed to by Dr. Davidson, and illustrated by references to the Gospel. What, in the name of common sense, is the value of such criticism as this? What is to be thought of a gentleman who blows hot and cold in the same breath: denying at p. 170 the genuineness of a certain portion of Scripture because it exhibits the very peculiarities which at p. 151 he had volunteered the information are characteristic of its reputed Author?

N.T. vol. i. Prolegg. p. 38.
254.

It may be convenient, in this place, to enumerate the several words and expressions about to be considered:‚Äî

(i.) œÄœÅ·ΩΩœÑŒ∑ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ (ver. 9.)‚ÄîSee above.

(ii.) ·ºÄœÜ·æΩ ·º¶œÇ ·ºêŒ∫Œ≤ŒµŒ≤Œª·ΩµŒ∫ŒµŒπ ·ºëœÄœÑ·Ω∞ Œ¥Œ±ŒπŒº·ΩπŒΩŒ∏Œ± (ver. 9.)‚ÄîSee p. 152.

(iii.) ·ºêŒ∫Œ≤·Ω±ŒªŒªŒµŒπŒΩ ·ºÄœÄ·Ωπ (ver. 9.)‚ÄîSee p. 153.

(iv.) œÄŒøœÅŒµ·ΩªŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ (vers. 10, 12, 15.)‚ÄîIbid.

(v.) Œø·º± ŒºŒµœÑ·æΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑŒø·ø¶ Œ≥ŒµŒΩ·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒøŒπ (ver. 10.)‚ÄîSee p. 155.

263.

The Sabbath-day, in the Old Testament, is invariably ◊™◊ë◊© (shabbath): a word which the Greeks could not exhibit more nearly than by the word œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒøŒΩ. The Chaldee form of this word is ◊ê◊™◊ë◊© (shabbatha:) the final ◊ê (a) being added for emphasis, as in Abba, Aceldama, Bethesda, Cepha, Pascha, &c.: and this form,‚Äî(I owe the information to my friend Professor Gandell,)‚Äîbecause it was so familiar to the people of Palestine, (who spoke Aramaic,) gave rise to another form of the Greek name for the Sabbath,‚Äîviz. œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ±: which, naturally enough, attracted the article (œÑ·Ωπ) into agreement with its own (apparently) plural form. By the Greek-speaking population of Jud√¶a, the Sabbath day was therefore indifferently called œÑŒø œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒøŒΩ and œÑŒ± œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ±: sometimes again, Œ∑ Œ∑ŒºŒµœÅŒ± œÑŒøœÖ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒøœÖ, and sometimes Œ∑ Œ∑ŒºŒµœÅŒ± œÑœâŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑœâŒΩ.

Œ£·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ±, although plural in sound, was strictly singular in sense. (Accordingly, it is invariably rendered ‚ÄúSabbatum‚Äù in the Vulgate.) Thus, in Exod. xvi. 23,‚ÄîœÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ± ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±œÄŒ±œÖœÉŒπœÇ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑Œ± œÑ·ø∑ ŒöœÖœÅ·Ω∑·ø≥: and 25,‚Äî·ºîœÉœÑŒπ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ± ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±œÄŒ±œÖœÉŒπœÇ œÑ·ø∑ ŒöœÖœÅ·Ω∑·ø≥. Again,‚ÄîœÑ·øá Œ¥·Ω≤ ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅŒ± œÑ·øá ·ºëŒ≤Œ¥·ΩπŒºŒ∑ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ±. (Exod. xvi. 26: xxxi. 14. Levit. xxiii. 3.) And in the Gospel, what took place on one definite Sabbath-day, is said to have occurred ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÉŒπ (S. Luke xiii. 10. S. Mark xii. 1.)

It will, I believe, be invariably found that the form ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÉŒπ is strictly equivalent to ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑ·ø≥; and was adopted for convenience in contradistinction to ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøŒπœÇ (1 Chron. xxiii. 31 and 2 Chron. ii. 4) where Sabbath days are spoken of.

It is not correct to say that in Levit. xxiii. 15 ◊™◊ï◊™◊ë◊© is put for ‚Äúweeks;‚Äù though the Septuagint translators have (reasonably enough) there rendered the word ·ºëŒ≤Œ¥ŒøŒº·Ω±Œ¥Œ±œÇ. In Levit. xxv. 8, (where the same word occurs twice,) it is once rendered ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÄŒ±·ΩªœÉŒµŒπœÇ; once, ·ºëŒ≤Œ¥ŒøŒº·Ω±Œ¥ŒµœÇ. Quite distinct is ◊¢◊ï◊ë◊© (shavooa) i.e. ·ºëŒ≤Œ¥ŒøŒº·Ω±œÇ; nor is there any substitution of the one word for the other. But inasmuch as the recurrence of the Sabbath-day was what constituted a week; in other words, since the essential feature of a week, as a Jewish division of time, was the recurrence of the Jewish day of rest;‚ÄîœÑ·Ω∏ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒøŒΩ or œÑ·Ω∞ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒ±, the Hebrew name for the day of rest, became transferred to the week. The former designation, (as explained in the text,) is used once by S. Mark, once by S. Luke; while the phrase Œº·Ω∑Œ± œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ occurs in the N.T., in all, six times.

264.
So Eusebius (Eccl. Hist. ii. 15), and Jerome (De Viris Illust. ii. 827), on the authority of Clemens Alex. and of Papias. See also Euseb. Hist. Eccl. vi. 14.‚ÄîThe colophon in the Syriac Version shews that the same traditional belief prevailed in the Eastern Church. It also finds record in the Synopsis Scriptur√¶ (wrongly) ascribed to Athanasius.

œÄŒ±œÅŒ±Œ≤·Ω±ŒªŒªŒµŒπŒΩ [I quote from the Textus Receptus of S. 296.
Exactly so Professor Broadus:‚Äî‚ÄúNow it will not do to say that while no one of these peculiarities would itself prove the style to be foreign to Mark, the whole of them combined will do so. It is very true that the multiplication of littles may amount to much; but not so the multiplication of nothings. And how many of the expressions which are cited, appear, in the light of our examination, to retain the slightest real force as proving difference of authorship? Is it not true that most of them, and those the most important, are reduced to absolutely nothing, while the remainder possess scarcely any appreciable significance?‚Äù‚Äîp. 360, (see above, p. 139, note g.)

302.

The reader will be perhaps interested with the following passage in the pages of Professor Broadus already (p. 139 note g) alluded to:‚Äî‚ÄúIt occurred to me to examine the twelve just preceding verses, (xv. 44 to xvi. 8,) and by a curious coincidence, the words and expressions not elsewhere employed by Mark, footed up precisely the same number, seventeen. Those noticed are the following (text of Tregelles):‚Äîver. 44, œÑ·Ω≥Œ∏Œ∑Œ∫ŒµŒΩ (elsewhere ·ºÄœÄŒøŒ∏ŒΩ·ΩµœÉŒ∫Œø):‚Äîver. 45, Œ≥ŒΩŒø·Ω∫œÇ ·ºÄœÄ·Ωπ, a construction found nowhere else in the New Testament: also ·ºêŒ¥œâœÅ·ΩµœÉŒ±œÑŒø and œÄœÑ·ø∂ŒºŒ±: ver. 46, ·ºêŒΩŒµ·Ω∑ŒªŒ∑œÉŒµŒΩ, ŒªŒµŒªŒ±œÑŒøŒºŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒΩ, œÄ·Ω≥œÑœÅŒ±œÇ, œÄœÅŒøœÉŒµŒ∫·ΩªŒªŒπœÉŒµŒΩ:‚Äîchap. xvi. ver. 1, Œ¥ŒπŒ±Œ≥ŒµŒΩŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖ, and ·ºÄœÅ·ΩΩŒºŒ±œÑŒ±: ver. 2, ŒºŒπ·æ∑ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ:‚Äîver. 3, ·ºÄœÄŒøŒ∫œÖŒª·Ω∑œÉŒµŒπ:‚Äîver. 4, ·ºÄŒΩŒµŒ∫ŒµŒ∫·ΩªŒªŒπœÉœÑŒ±Œπ. Also, œÉœÜ·ΩπŒ¥œÅŒ±, (Mark's word is Œª·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ.) Ver. 5, ·ºÄŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œ¥ŒµŒæŒπŒø·øñœÇ is a construction not found in Mark, or the other Gospels, though the word Œ¥ŒµŒæŒπ·ΩπœÇ occurs frequently:‚Äîver. 8, Œµ·º∂œáŒµŒΩ, in this particular sense, not elsewhere in the New Testament: œÑœÅ·ΩπŒºŒøœÇ.

‚ÄúThis list is perhaps not complete, for it was prepared in a few hours‚Äîabout as much time, it may be said, without disrespect, as Fritsche and Meyer appear to have given to their collections of examples from the other passage. It is not proposed to discuss the list, though some of the instances are curious. It is not claimed that they are all important, but that they are all real. And as regards the single question of the number of peculiarities, they certainly form quite an offset to the number upon which Dean Alford has laid stress.‚Äù‚Äîp. 361.

326.
The one memorable exception, which I have only lately met with, is supplied by the following remark of the thoughtful and accurate Matthaei, made in a place where it was almost safe to escape attention; viz. in a footnote at the very end of his Nov. Test. (ed. 1803), vol. i. p. 748.‚Äî‚ÄúHaec lectio in Evangeliariis et Synaxariis omnibus ter notatur tribus maxime notabilibus temporibus. Secundum ordinem temporum Ecclesiae Graecae primo legitur Œ∫œÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫·øá œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºœÖœÅŒøœÜ·ΩπœÅœâŒΩ, Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ΩÑœÅŒ∏œÅŒøŒΩ. Secundo, œÑ·ø∑ ·ΩÑœÅŒ∏œÅ·ø≥ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œª·ΩµœàŒµœâœÇ. Tertio, ut ·ºëœâŒ∏ŒπŒΩ·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÉŒπŒºŒøŒΩ Œ≥·æΩ. De hoc loco ergo vetustissimis temporibus nullo modo dubitavit Ecclesia.‚Äù‚ÄîMatthaei had slightly anticipated this in his ed. of 1788, vol. ii. 267.
327.
Œ§·Ω∞œÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·º±ŒµœÅ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒªœâŒΩ Œ¥ŒπŒ±Œ¥Œøœá·Ω±œÇ,‚Äîare the first words of the Ecclesiatical History of Eusebius.

330.
Œ§·øá œÑŒø·ø¶ ·º°Œª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ ŒªŒµŒ≥ŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩ·øÉ ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥, œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÄ·ΩπŒªŒµŒπœÇ ·º• ·ºÄŒ≥œÅŒø·Ω∫œÇ ŒºŒµŒΩ·ΩπŒΩœÑœâŒΩ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ œÉœÖŒΩ·Ω≥ŒªŒµœÖœÉŒπœÇ Œ≥·Ω∑ŒΩŒµœÑŒ±Œπ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄœÄŒøŒºŒΩŒ∑ŒºŒøŒΩŒµ·ΩªŒºŒ±œÑŒ± œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒªœâŒΩ, ·º§ œÑ·Ω∞ œÉœÖŒ≥Œ≥œÅ·Ω±ŒºŒºŒ±œÑŒ± œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄœÅŒøœÜŒ∑œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒµœÑŒ±Œπ, Œº·Ω≥œáœÅŒπœÇ ·ºêŒ≥œáœâœÅŒµ·øñ. Then came the Sermon,‚Äîthen, all stood and prayed,‚Äîthen followed Holy Communion.‚ÄîApol. i. c. 67, (ed. Otto, i. 158.)
331.
·ΩÅ Œº·Ω±œÑŒ∑ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩœÑŒ±·ø¶Œ∏Œ± Œµ·º∞œÉŒµŒªŒ∏·ΩºŒΩ, Œµ·º∞œÄ·Ω≤, œÑ·Ω∑œÇ œÄœÅŒøœÜ·ΩµœÑŒ∑œÇ, œÄŒø·øñŒøœÇ ·ºÄœÄ·ΩπœÉœÑŒøŒªŒøœÇ ·º°Œº·øñŒΩ œÉ·ΩµŒºŒµœÅŒøŒΩ Œ¥Œπ·Ω≥ŒªœáŒ∏Œ∑, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∑ŒΩœâŒΩ;‚Äî(Opp. ix. p. 697 e. Field's text.)
332.
Cassian writes,‚Äî‚ÄúVenerabilis Patrum senatus ... decrevit hunc numerum [sc. duodecim Orationum] tam in Vespertinis quam in Nocturnis conventiculis custodiri; quibus lectiones geminas adjungentes, id est, unam Veteris et aliam Novi Testamenti.... In die vero Sabbati vel Dominico utrasque de Novo recitant Testamento; id est, unam de Apostolo vel Actibus Apostolorum, et aliam de Evangeliis. Quod etiam totis Quinquagesimae diebus faciunt hi, quibus lectio curae est, seu memoria Scripturarum.‚Äù‚ÄîInstit. lib. ii. c. 6. (ed.1733, p. 18.)
333.
Constitutiones Apostolicae, lib. ii. c. 57, 59: v. 19: viii. 5.
334.

335.

Thus, the Œ∫œÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫·Ωµ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÑœÖœÅŒøœÜ·Ω±Œ≥ŒøœÖ is ‚ÄúQuinquagesima Sunday;‚Äù but the week of ‚Äúthe cheese-eater‚Äù is the week previous.

ŒöŒ±·Ω∂ ·º° Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ± œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ¥ŒπŒ¥Œ±œÉŒ∫Œ±Œª·Ω∑Œ±œÇ [cf. Cyril, p. 4, lines 16-7] œÑ·øÜœÇ œÄ·Ω∑œÉœÑŒµœâœÇ œÄœÅŒø·Ω≥œÑœÅŒµœÄŒµŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÄŒµ·øñŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºàŒΩŒ±Œª·ΩµœàŒµœâœÇ: ·ºÄŒªŒª·æΩ ·º° œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒòŒµŒø·ø¶ œá·Ω±œÅŒπœÇ ·æ†Œ∫ŒøŒΩ·ΩπŒºŒ∑œÉŒµ œÄŒªŒ∑œÅ·Ω≥œÉœÑŒ±œÑ·Ω± œÉŒµ ·ºÄŒ∫Œø·ø¶œÉŒ±Œπ, Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·º°ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒ±ŒΩ ·ºÄœÉŒ∏·Ω≥ŒΩŒµŒπŒ±ŒΩ, œÑ·øá œáŒ∏·Ω≤œÇ ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·øÜŒΩ ŒöœÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫·ΩµŒΩ: Œ∫Œ±œÑ·æΩ Œø·º∞Œ∫ŒøŒΩŒøŒº·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ∏Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ œá·Ω±œÅŒπœÑŒøœÇ, ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·øá Œ£œÖŒΩ·Ω±ŒæŒµŒπ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒΩœâœÉŒº·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ±œÇ œÑ·Ω∞ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œµ·º∞œÇ Œø·ΩêœÅŒ±ŒΩŒø·Ω∫œÇ ·ºÄŒΩ·ΩπŒ¥ŒøœÖ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ£œâœÑ·øÜœÅŒøœÇ ·º°Œº·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒµœáŒø·ΩªœÉŒ∑œÇ: ·ºêŒª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµœÑŒø Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·Ω∞ ŒªŒµŒ≥·ΩπŒºŒµŒΩŒ±, Œº·Ω±ŒªŒπœÉœÑŒ± Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œ¥Œπ·Ω∞ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒ±œÇ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ¥Œπ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒπœÉœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ΩÅŒºŒø·ø¶ œÄŒª·øÜŒ∏ŒøœÇ: ·ºêŒæŒ±ŒπœÅ·Ω≥œÑœâœÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œ¥Œπ·Ω± œÉŒµ: Œ∂Œ∑œÑŒµ·øñœÑŒ±Œπ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œµ·º∞ œÄœÅŒøœÉ·Ω≥œÉœáŒµœÇ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ŒªŒµŒ≥ŒøŒº·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒπœÇ. Œü·º∂Œ¥Œ±œÇ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ΩÖœÑŒπ ·º° ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ± œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ†·Ω∑œÉœÑŒµœâœÇ Œ¥ŒπŒ¥·Ω±œÉŒ∫ŒµŒπ œÉŒµ œÄŒπœÉœÑŒµ·ΩªŒµŒπŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÇ Œ§ŒüŒù ·ºàŒùŒëŒ£Œ§ŒëŒùŒ§Œë Œ§Œó Œ§Œ°ŒôŒ§Œó ŒóŒúŒïŒ°Œë: ŒöŒëŒô ·ºàŒùŒïŒõŒòŒüŒùŒ§Œë ŒïŒôŒ£ Œ§ŒüŒ•Œ£ ŒüŒ•Œ°ŒëŒùŒüŒ•Œ£, ŒöŒëŒô ŒöŒëŒòŒôŒ£ŒëŒùŒ§Œë ·ºòŒö ŒîŒïŒûŒôŒ©Œù Œ§ŒüŒ• Œ†ŒëŒ§Œ°ŒüŒ£‚ÄîŒº·Ω±ŒªŒπœÉœÑŒ± Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œø·ΩñŒΩ ŒºŒΩŒ∑ŒºŒøŒΩŒµ·ΩªŒµŒπŒΩ œÉŒµ ŒΩŒøŒº·Ω∑Œ∂œâ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºêŒæŒ∑Œ≥·ΩµœÉŒµœâœÇ. œÄŒª·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ œÄŒ±œÅŒ±Œ¥œÅŒøŒº·øá Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ŒΩ·ø¶ŒΩ ·ΩëœÄŒøŒºŒπŒºŒΩ·ΩµœÉŒ∫œâ œÉŒµ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÅŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩœâŒΩ. (Cyril. Hier. Cat. xiv. c. 24. Opp. p. 217 C, D.)‚ÄîOf that Sermon of his, Cyril again and again reminds his auditory. Œú·Ω≥ŒºŒΩŒ∑œÉŒø Œ¥·Ω≤ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÅŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩœâŒΩ ŒºŒøŒπ œÄŒøŒªŒª·Ω±Œ∫ŒπœÇ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶, ·ºêŒ∫ Œ¥ŒµŒæŒπ·ø∂ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÄŒ±œÑœÅŒøœÇ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·Ω≥Œ∂ŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ•·º±·Ω∏ŒΩ,‚Äîhe says, ibid. p. 219 B. A little lower down, Œù·ø¶ŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ΩëŒº·æ∂œÇ ·ΩëœÄŒøŒºŒΩŒ∑œÉœÑ·Ω≥ŒøŒΩ ·ΩÄŒª·Ω∑Œ≥œâŒΩ, œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºêŒ∫ œÄŒøŒªŒª·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·º∞œÅŒ∑Œº·Ω≥ŒΩœâŒΩ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶, ·ºêŒ∫ Œ¥ŒµŒπŒæ·ø∂ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ†Œ±œÑœÅ·Ω∏œÇ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·Ω≥Œ∂ŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ•·º±·ΩπŒΩ.‚ÄîIbid. D.

From this it becomes plain why Cyril nowhere quotes S. Mark xvi. 19,‚Äîor S. Luke xxiv. 51,‚Äîor Acts i. 9. He must needs have enlarged upon those three inevitable places of Scripture, the day before.

See above, p. 193 and p. 194.
341.
·Ω≠œÉœÑŒµ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œµ·ΩêŒºŒ±Œ∏·Ω≥œÉœÑŒµœÅŒøŒΩ Œ≥ŒµŒΩ·Ω≥œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œª·ΩπŒ≥ŒøŒΩ, Œ¥Œµ·ΩπŒºŒµŒ∏Œ± Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÄŒ±œÅŒ±Œ∫Œ±ŒªŒø·ø¶ŒºŒµŒΩ, ·ΩÖœÄŒµœÅ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÑŒªŒªœâŒΩ Œ≥œÅŒ±œÜ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒµœÄŒøŒπ·ΩµŒ∫Œ±ŒºŒµŒΩ, œÄœÅŒøŒªŒ±ŒºŒ≤·Ω±ŒΩŒµŒπŒΩ, œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ∫ŒøœÄ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ≥œÅŒ±œÜ·øÜœÇ ·º¶ŒΩ ·ºÜŒΩ Œº·Ω≥ŒªŒªœâŒºŒµŒΩ ·ºêŒæŒ∑ŒΩŒµ·øñœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ.‚ÄîIn Matth. Hom. i. (Opp. vii. 13 B.)‚ÄîŒöŒ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œº·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ, ·º• Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÉ·Ω±Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒøŒΩ, œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ Œº·Ω≥ŒªŒªŒøœÖœÉŒ±ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ ·ΩëŒº·øñŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒΩœâœÉŒ∏·ΩµœÉŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑œâŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ∫ŒøœÄ·Ω¥ŒΩ, œÑŒ±·ΩªœÑŒ∑ŒΩ œÄœÅ·Ω∏ œÑŒø·ΩªœÑœâŒΩ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·º°ŒºŒµœÅ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ œáŒµ·øñœÅŒ±œÇ ŒªŒ±ŒºŒ≤·Ω±ŒΩœâŒΩ ·ºïŒ∫Œ±œÉœÑŒøœÇ Œø·º¥Œ∫ŒøŒπ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·ΩµŒºŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩœâœÉŒ∫·Ω≥œÑœâ.‚ÄîIn Joann. Hom. ix, (Opp. viii. 62 B.)
342.
It caused him (he says) to interrupt his teaching. ‚ÄúSed quia nunc interposita est sollemnitas sanctorum dierum, quibus certas ex Evangelio lectiones oportet in Ecclesi√¢ recitari, quae ita sunt annuae ut aliae esse non possint; ordo ille quem susceperamus necessitate pauliulum intermissus est, non amissus.‚Äù‚Äî(Opp. vol. iii. P. ii. p. 825, Prol.)
343.
The place will be found quoted below, p. 202, note (o).
344.
See Suicer, (i. 247 and 9: ii. 673). He is much more full and satisfactory than Scholz, whose remarks, nevertheless, deserve attention, (Nov. Test. vol. i, Prolegg. p. xxxi.) See also above, p. 45, notes (r) and (s).
345.

At the beginning of every volume of the first ed. of his Nov. Test. (Riga, 1788) Matthaei has laboriously edited the ‚ÄúLectiones Ecclesiastic√¶‚Äù of the Greek Church. See also his Appendices,‚Äîviz. vol. ii. pp. 272-318 and 322-363. His 2nd ed. (Wittenberg, 1803,) is distinguished by the valuable peculiarity of indicating the Ecclesiastical sections throughout, in the manner of an ancient MS.; and that, with extraordinary fulness and accuracy. His Œ£œÖŒΩŒ±œá·Ω±œÅŒπŒ± (i. 723-68 and iii. 1-24) though not intelligible perhaps to ordinary readers, are very important. He derived them from MSS. which he designates ‚ÄúB‚Äù and ‚ÄúH,‚Äù but which are our ‚ÄúEvstt. 47 and 50,‚Äù‚Äîuncial Evangelistaria of the viiith century (See Scrivener's Introd. p. 214.)

Scholz, at the end of vol. i. of his N. T. p. 453-93, gives in full the ‚ÄúSynaxarium‚Äù and ‚ÄúMenologium‚Äù of Codd. K and M, (viiith or ixth century.) See also his vol. ii. pp. 456-69. Unfortunately, (as Scrivener recognises, p. 110,) all here is carelessly done,‚Äîas usual with this Editor; and therefore to a great extent useless. His slovenliness is extraordinary. The ‚ÄúGospels of the Passion‚Äù (œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑œâŒΩ œÄ·Ω±Œ∏œâŒΩ), he entitles œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑œâŒΩ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑœâŒΩ (p. 472); and so throughout.

Mr. Scrivener (Introduction, pp. 68-75,) has given by far the most intelligible account of this matter, by exhibiting in English the Lectionary of the Eastern Church, (‚Äúgathered chiefly from Evangelist. Arund. 547, Parham 18, Harl. 5598, Burney 22, and Christ's Coll. Camb.‚Äù); and supplying the references to Scripture in the ordinary way. See, by all means, his Introduction, pp. 62-65: also, pp. 211-225.

346.

Consider the following:‚Äî·ºòŒΩ œÑ·øá ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉœÑŒ±œÖœÅŒø·ø¶ œÑ·Ω∞ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉœÑŒ±œÖœÅŒø·ø¶ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒ± ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒøŒºŒµŒΩ. ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·ø∑ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑ·ø≥ œÑ·ø∑ ŒºŒµŒ≥·Ω±Œª·ø≥ œÄ·Ω±ŒªŒπŒΩ, ·ΩÖœÑŒπ œÄŒ±œÅŒµŒ¥·ΩπŒ∏Œ∑ ·º°Œº·ø∂ŒΩ ·ΩÅ Œö·ΩªœÅŒπŒøœÇ, ·ΩÖœÑŒπ ·ºêœÉœÑŒ±œÖœÅ·ΩΩŒ∏Œ∑, ·ΩÖœÑŒπ ·ºÄœÄ·Ω≥Œ∏Œ±ŒΩŒµ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ œÉ·Ω±œÅŒ∫Œ±, ·ΩÖœÑŒπ ·ºêœÑ·Ω±œÜŒ∑: œÑ·Ω∑ŒΩŒøœÇ Œø·ΩñŒΩ ·ºïŒΩŒµŒ∫ŒµŒΩ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞œÇ œÄœÅ·Ω±ŒæŒµŒπœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÉœÑ·ΩπŒªœâŒΩ Œø·Ωê ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄŒµŒΩœÑŒ∑Œ∫ŒøœÉœÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒøŒºŒµŒΩ, ·ΩÖœÑŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºêŒ≥·Ω≥ŒΩŒøŒΩœÑŒø, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄœÅœá·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºîŒªŒ±Œ≤ŒøŒΩ;‚ÄîChrys. Opp. iii. 88.

Again:‚ÄîŒµ·º∞ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑ·ΩπœÑŒµ ·º•œÅŒæŒ±ŒΩœÑŒø œÄŒøŒπŒµ·øñŒΩ œÑ·Ω∞ œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµ·øñŒ± Œø·º± ·ºÄœÄ·ΩπœÉœÑŒøŒªŒøŒπ, ·º§Œ≥ŒøœÖŒΩ ŒºŒµœÑ·Ω∞ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ Œ∫œÖœÅ·Ω∑ŒøœÖ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω±œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒπŒΩ, œÑ·ΩπœÑŒµ ·ºîŒ¥ŒµŒπ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ≤ŒπŒ≤Œª·Ω∑ŒøŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ œÑŒø·ø¶œÑŒø. ·Ω•œÉœÄŒµœÅ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑ·Ω∞ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉœÑŒ±œÖœÅŒø·ø¶ ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·øá ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥ œÉœÑŒ±œÖœÅŒø·ø¶ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒøŒºŒµŒΩ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºêŒΩ œÑ·øá ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÉŒµŒπ ·ΩÅŒºŒø·Ω∑œâœÇ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºêŒΩ ·ºêŒ∫·Ω±œÉœÑ·øÉ ·ºëŒøœÅœÑ·øá Œ≥ŒµŒ≥ŒøŒΩ·ΩπœÑŒ± œÑ·øá Œ±·ΩêœÑ·øá œÄ·Ω±ŒªŒπŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒøŒºŒµŒΩ, Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ ·ºîŒ¥ŒµŒπ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∞ Œ∏Œ±·ΩªŒºŒ±œÑŒ± œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÉœÑŒøŒªŒπŒ∫·Ω∞ ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒ±·øñœÇ ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅŒ±ŒπœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄœÄŒøœÉœÑŒøŒªŒπŒ∫·ø∂ŒΩ œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµ·Ω∑œâŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒµœÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ.‚ÄîIbid. p. 89 D.

355.
‚ÄúAnniversari√¢ sollemnitate post passionem Domini nostis illum librum recitari.‚Äù Opp. iii. (P. ii.) p. 337 g.
356.

I desire to leave in this place the permanent record of my deliberate conviction that the Lectionary which, last year, was hurried with such indecent haste through Convocation,‚Äîpassed in a half-empty House by the casting vote of the Prolocutor,‚Äîand rudely pressed upon the Church's acceptance by the Legislature in the course of its present session,‚Äîis the gravest calamity which has befallen the Church of England for a long time past.

Let the history of this Lectionary be remembered.

Appointed (in 1867) for an entirely different purpose, (viz. the Ornaments and Vestments question,) 29 Commissioners (14 Clerical and 15 Lay) found themselves further instructed ‚Äúto suggest and report whether any and what alterations and amendments may be advantageously made in the selection of Lessons to be read at the time of Divine Service.‚Äù

Thereupon, these individuals,‚Äî(the Liturgical attainments of nine-tenths of whom it would be unbecoming in such an one as myself to characterise truthfully,)‚Äîat once imposed upon themselves the duty of inventing an entirely new Lectionary for the Church of England.

So to mutilate the Word of God that it shall henceforth be quite impossible to understand a single Bible story, or discover the sequence of a single connected portion of narrative,‚Äîseems to have been the guiding principle of their deliberations. With reckless eclecticism,‚Äîentire forgetfulness of the requirements of the poor brother,‚Äîstrange disregard for Catholic Tradition and the claims of immemorial antiquity;‚Äîthese Commissioners, (evidently unconscious of their own unfitness for their self-imposed task,) have given us a Lectionary which will recommend itself to none but the lovers of novelty,‚Äîthe impatient,‚Äîand the enemies of Divine Truth.

That the blame, the guilt lies at the door of our Bishops, is certain; but the Church has no one but herself to thank for the injury which has been thus deliberately inflicted upon her. She has suffered herself to be robbed of her ancient birthright without resistance; without remonstrance; without (in her corporate capacity) so much as a word of audible dissatisfaction. Can it be right in this way to defraud those who are to come after us of their lawful inheritance?... I am amazed and grieved beyond measure at what is taking place. At least, (as on other occasions,) liberavi animam meam.

357.
A trace of this remains in the old Gallican Liturgy,‚Äîpp. 137-8.

362.
‚ÄúPassio autem, quia uno die legitur, non solet legi nisi secundum Matth√¶um. Voluerain aliquando ut per singulos annos secundum omnes Evangelistas etiam Passio legeretur. Factum est. Non audierunt homines quod consueverant, et perturbati sunt.‚Äù‚ÄîOpp. vol. v. p. 980 e.

366.

367.

The learned reader will be delighted and instructed too by the perusal of both passages. Chrysostom declares that Christmas-Day is the greatest of Festivals; since all the others are but consequences of the Incarnation.

Epiphanius remarks with truth that Ascension-Day is the crowning solemnity of all: being to the others what a beautiful head is to the human body.

368.
Constt. Apostt. lib. viii. c. 33. After the week of the Passion and the week of (1) the Resurrection,‚Äî(2) Ascension-Day is mentioned;‚Äî(3) Pentecost;‚Äî(4) Nativity;‚Äî(5) Epiphany. [Note this clear indication that this viiith Book of the Constitutions was written or interpolated at a subsequent date to that commonly assigned to the work.]

Sicut quod Domini Passio, et Resurrectio, et Ascensio in c≈ìlis, ut Adventus de c≈ìlo Spiritus Sancti anniversaria sollemnitate celebrantur.‚Äù‚ÄîEp. ad Januarium, (Opp. ii. 124 b, c).

389.
So Scrivener's Introduction, p. 75.‚ÄîLittle stress, however, is to be laid on Saint's Day lessons. In Matthaei's ‚ÄúMenologium‚Äù (Nov. Test. 1803, i. p. 765), I find that S. Luke viii. 1-4, or else S. John xx. 11-18 was the appointed Lection. See his note (5) at p. 750.
390.
Note, (in addition to all that has gone before,) that the Festivals are actually designated by their Greek names in the earliest Latin Service Books: not only ‚ÄúTheophania,‚Äù ‚ÄúEpiphania,‚Äù ‚ÄúPascha,‚Äù ‚ÄúPentecostes,‚Äù (the second, third and fourth of which appellations survive in the Church of the West, in memoriam, to the present hour;) but ‚ÄúHypapante,‚Äù which was the title bestowed by the Orientals in the time of Justinian, on Candlemas Day, (our Feast of the Purification, or Presentation of Christ in the Temple,) from the ‚ÄúMeeting‚Äù of Symeon on that occasion. Friday, or œÄŒ±œÅŒ±œÉŒ∫ŒµœÖ·Ωµ, was called ‚ÄúParasceve‚Äù in the West. (Mab. Lit. Gall. p. 129.) So entire was the sympathy of the East with the West in such matters in very early times, that when Rome decided to celebrate the Nativity on the 25th December, Chrysostom (as we have been reminded) publicly announced the fact at Constantinople; and it was determined that in this matter East and West would walk by the same rule.
391.
From Professor Wright's Catalogue of Syriac MSS. in the British Museum (1870) it appears that the oldest Jacobite Lectionary is dated A.D. 824; the oldest Nestorian, A.D. 862; the oldest Malkite, A.D. 1023. The respective numbers of the MSS. are 14,485; 14,492; and 14,488.‚ÄîSee his Catalogue, Part I. pp. 146, 178, 194.
392.
It is exhibited in the same glass-case with the Cod. Alexandrinus (A.)

Augiensis,‚Äî80 pages which have been separately published and are well deserving of study,‚Äîp. 48,] who adds,‚Äî‚ÄúI cannot even conjecture why an Evangelistarium should be thought of less value than another MS. of the same age.‚Äù‚ÄîSee also Scrivener's Introduction, &c. p. 211.

399.
Thus the words Œµ·º∂œÄŒµ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ΩÅ Œö·ΩªœÅŒπŒøœÇ (S. Luke vii. 31) which introduce an Ecclesiastical Lection (Friday in the iiird week of S. Luke,) inasmuch as the words are found in no uncial MS., and are omitted besides by the Syriac, Vulgate, Gothic and Coptic Versions, must needs be regarded as a liturgical interpolation.‚ÄîThe same is to be said of ·ΩÅ ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒø·ø¶œÇ in S. Matth. xiv. 22,‚Äîwords which Origen and Chrysostom, as well as the Syriac versions, omit; and which clearly owe their place in twelve of the uncials, in the Textus Receptus, in the Vulgate and some copies of the old Latin, to the fact that the Gospel for the ixth Sunday after Pentecost begins at that place.‚ÄîIt will be kindred to the present inquiry that I should point out that in S. Mark xvi. 9, ·ºàŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÇ ·ΩÅ ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒø·ø¶œÇ is constantly met with in Greek MSS., and even in some copies of the Vulgate; and yet there can be no doubt that here also the Holy Name is an interpolation which has originated from the same cause as the preceding. The fact is singularly illustrated by the insertion of ‚ÄúŒü ŒôŒ£‚Äù in Cod. 267 ( = Reg. 69,) rubro above the same contraction (for ·ΩÅ ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒøœÖœÇ) in the text.
400.
Not, of course, so long as the present senseless fashion prevails of regarding Codex B, (to which, if Cod. L. and Codd. 1, 33 and 69 are added, it is only because they agree with B), as an all but infallible guide in settling the text of Scripture; and quietly taking it for granted that all the other MSS. in existence have entered into a grand conspiracy to deceive mankind. Until this most uncritical method, this most unphilosophical theory, is unconditionally abandoned, progress in this department of sacred Science is simply impossible.
401.
See Matthaei's note on S. Luke xxii. 43, (Nov. Test. ed. 1803.)
402.

This will be best understood by actual reference to a manuscript. In Cod. Evan. 436 (Meerman 117) which lies before me, these directions are given as follows. After œÑ·Ω∏ œÉ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œ≥ŒµŒΩ·Ω≥œÉŒ∏œâ (i.e. the last words of ver. 42), is written ·ΩëœÄ·Ω≥œÅŒ≤Œ± Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ≥·æΩ. Then, at the end of ver. 44, is written‚Äî·ºÑœÅœáŒøœÖ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ≥·æΩ, after which follows the text Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ, &c.

In S. Matthew's Gospel, at chap, xxvi, which contains the Liturgical section for Thursday in Holy Week (œÑ·øá ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑·æ≥ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ŒºŒµŒ≥·Ω±ŒªŒ∑ ·Ω≥), my Codex has been only imperfectly rubricated. Let me therefore be allowed to quote from Harl. MS. 1810, (our Cod. Evan. 113) which, at fol. 84, at the end of S. Matth. xxvi. 39, reads as follows, immediately after the words,‚ÄîŒ±ŒªŒª·æΩ ·Ω°œÇ œÉœÖ:‚ÄîŒ†/Œ•, [Cross] (i.e. ·ΩëœÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒ±.) But in order to explain what is meant, the above rubricated word and sign are repeated at foot, as follows:‚Äî[Cross] ·ΩëœÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒ± Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ ŒõŒøœÖŒ∫·Ω∞ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ Œ∫ŒµœÜŒ±ŒªŒ±·Ω∑·ø≥ Œ°Œò. ·Ω§œÜŒ∏Œ∑ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø≥ ·ºÑŒ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒøœÇ: Œµ·º∂œÑŒ± œÉœÑœÅŒ±œÜŒµ·Ω∂œÇ ·ºêŒΩœÑŒ±·ø¶Œ∏Œ± œÄ·Ω±ŒªŒπŒΩ, Œª·Ω≥Œ≥Œµ: Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºîœÅœáŒµœÑŒ±Œπ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ ŒºŒ±Œ∏Œ∑œÑ·Ω±œÇ‚Äîwhich are the first words of S. Matth. xxvi. 40.

Accordingly, my Codex (No. 436, above referred to) immediately after S. Luke xxii. 42, besides the rubric already quoted, has the following: ·ºÑœÅŒæŒøœÖ œÑ·øÜœÇ ŒºŒµŒ≥·Ω±ŒªŒ∑œÇ ·Ω≥. Then come the two famous verses (ver. 43, 44); and, after the words ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ ·ºÄœÄ·Ω∏ œÑ·øÜœÇ œÄœÅŒøœÉŒµœÖœá·øÜœÇ, the following rubric occurs: ·ΩëœÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒ± Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·øÜœÇ ŒºŒµŒ≥·Ω±ŒªŒ∑œÇ ·Ω≥ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏. ·ºîœÅœáŒµœÑŒ±Œπ œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ œÑŒø·ø¶œÇ ŒºŒ±Œ∏Œ∑œÑ·Ω±œÇ.

[With the help of my nephew, (Rev. W. F. Rose, Curate of Holy Trinity, Windsor,) I have collated every syllable of Cod. 436. Its text most nearly resembles the Rev. F. H. Scrivener's l, m, n.]

406.

408.
viz. œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑ·ø≥ Œ∏: i.e. the ixth Saturday in S. Luke.‚ÄîNote that Cod. A also reads ·ºêŒ≥·Ω≥ŒΩŒµœÑŒø Œ¥·Ω≥ in S. Lu. xi. 1.
409.
viz. Monday in the vth, Thursday in the vith week after Pentecost, and the viiith Sunday after Pentecost.
410.
viz. S. Luke xiii. 2: xxiv. 36. S. John i. 29 (·ΩÅ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑œÇ): 44: vi. 14: xiii. 3,‚Äîto which should perhaps be added xxi. 1, where B, ◊ê, A, C (not D) read ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒø·ø¶œÇ.
411.
See by all means Matthaei's interesting note on the place,‚ÄîNov. Test. (1788) vol. i. p. 113-4. It should be mentioned that Cod. C (and four other uncials), together with the Philoxenian and Hierosolymitan versions, concur in exhibiting the same spurious clause. Matthaei remarks,‚Äî‚ÄúOrigenes (iv. 171 d) hanc pericopam haud adeo diligenter recensens terminat eum in Œ≥ŒµŒΩŒ∑Œ∏·ΩµœÑœâ œÉŒøŒπ.‚Äù Will not the disturbing Lectionary-practice of his day sufficiently explain Origen's omission?
412.
I recall S. John x. 29: xix. 13: xxi. 1;‚Äîbut the attentive student will be able to multiply such references almost indefinitely. In these and similar places, while the phraseology is exceedingly simple, the variations which the text exhibits are so exceeding numerous,‚Äîthat when it is discovered that a Church Lesson begins in those places, we may be sure that we have been put in possession of the name of the disturbing force.
413.
Viz. K and M. (Field's Chrys. p. 251.)‚ÄîHow is it that the readings of Chrysostom are made so little account of? By Tregelles, for example, why are they overlooked entirely?
414.
See above, p. 197 to 204.
415.
e.g. in Cod. Evan. 10 and 270.
416.
In some cursive MSS. also, (which have been probably transcribed from ancient originals), the same phenomenon is observed. Thus, in Evan. 265 ( = Reg. 66), Œ§ŒïŒõ only occurs, in S. Mark, at ix. 9 and 41: xv. 32 and 41: xvi. 8. ŒëŒ°Œß at xvi. 1. It is striking to observe that so little were these ecclesiastical notes (embedded in the text) understood by the possessor of the MS., that in the margin, over against ch. xv. 41, (where ‚ÄúŒ§ŒïŒõ:‚Äù stands in the text,) a somewhat later hand has written,‚ÄîŒ§Œï[ŒªŒøœÇ] Œ§[Œ∑œÇ] Œ©Œ°[Œ±œÇ]. A similar liturgical note may be seen over against ch. ix. 9, and elsewhere. Cod. 25 (= Reg. 191), at the end of S. Mark's Gospel, has only two notes of liturgical endings: viz. at ch. xv. 1 and 42.
417.
Among the Syriac Evangelia, as explained above (p. 215), instances occur of far more ancient MSS. which exhibit a text rubricated by the original scribe. Even here, however, (as may be learned from Dr. Wright's Catalogue, pp. 46-66,) such Rubrics have been only irregularly inserted in the oldest copies.
418.

Note, that the Codex from which Cod. D was copied will have exhibited the text thus,‚ÄîŒëŒ†ŒïŒßŒïŒô Œ§Œü Œ§ŒïŒõŒüŒ£ ŒóŒõŒòŒïŒù Œó Œ©Œ°Œë.‚Äîwhich is the reading of Cod. 13 ( = Reg. 50.) But the scribe of Cod. D, in order to improve the sense, substituted for ·º¶ŒªŒ∏ŒµŒΩ the word Œ∫Œ±·Ω∑. Note the scholion [Anon. Vat.] in Possinus, p. 321:‚Äî·ºÄœÄ·Ω≥œáŒµŒπ, œÑŒøœÖœÑ·Ω≥œÉœÑŒπ, œÄŒµœÄŒª·ΩµœÅœâœÑŒ±Œπ, œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ ·ºîœáŒµŒπ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·æΩ ·ºêŒº·Ω≥.

Besides the said Cod. 13, the same reading is found in 47 and 54 (in the Bodl.): 56 (at Linc. Coll.): 61 (i.e. Cod. Montfort.): 69 (i.e. Cod. Leicestr.): 124 (i.e. Cod. Vind. Lamb. 31): csecr (i.e. Lambeth, 1177): 2pe (i.e. the 2nd of Muralt's S. Petersburg Codd.); and Cod. 439 (i.e. Addit. Brit. Mus. 5107). All these eleven MSS. read ·ºÄœÄ·Ω≥œáŒµŒπ œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ at S. Mark xiv. 41.

419.
So Scholz (i. 200):‚Äî‚ÄúPericopa h√¶c casu quodam forsan exciderat a codice quodam Alexandrino; unde defectus iste in alios libros transiit. Nec mirum hunc defectum multis, immo in certis regionibus plerisque scribis arrisisse: confitentur enim ex ipsorum opinione Marcum Matth√¶o repugnare. Cf. maxima Eusebium ad Marinum,‚Äù &c.
420.
œÄŒµœÅŒπœÑœÑ·Ω∞ ·Ω∞ŒΩ Œµ·º¥Œ∑, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œº·Ω±ŒªŒπœÉœÑŒ± Œµ·º¥œÄŒµœÅ ·ºîœáŒøŒπŒµŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒªŒøŒ≥·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÑ·øá œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒªŒøŒπœÄ·ø∂ŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπœÉœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºŒ±œÅœÑœÖœÅ·Ω∑·æ≥. (Mai, Bibl. P.P. Nova, vol. iv. p. 256.)
421.
Alford's N.T. vol. i. p. 433, (ed. 1868.)‚ÄîAnd so Tischendorf, (ed. 8va. pp. 406-7.) ‚ÄúTalem dissentionem ad Marci librum tam misere mutilandum adduxisse quempiam, et quidem tanto cum successu, prorsus incredibile est, nec ullo probari potest exemplo.‚Äù‚ÄîTregelles is of the same opinion. (Printed Text, pp. 255-6.)‚ÄîMatthaei, a competent judge, seems to have thought differently. ‚ÄúUna autem causa cur hic locus omitteretur fuit quod Marcus in his repugnare ceteris videtur Evangelistis.‚Äù The general observation which follows is true enough:‚Äî‚ÄúQu√¶ ergo vel obscura, vel repugnantia, vel parum decora quorundam opinione habebantur, ca olim ab Criticis et interpretibus nonnullis vel sublata, vel in dubium vocata esse, ex aliis locis sanctorum Evangeliorum intelligitur.‚Äù (Nov. Test. 1788, vol. ii. p. 266.) Presently, (at p. 270,)‚Äî‚ÄúIn summ√¢. Videtur unus et item alter ex interpretibus, qui h√¶c c√¶teris evangeliis repugnare opinebatur, in dubium vocasse. Hunc deinde plures temere secuti sunt, ut plerumque factum esse animadvertimus.‚Äù Dr. Davidson says the same thing (ii. 116.) and, (what is of vastly more importance,) Mr. Scrivener also. (Coll. Cod. Sin. p. xliv.)
422.
I have to acknowledge very gratefully the obliging attentions of M. de Wailly, the chief of the Manuscript department.
423.

424.
Whereas in the course of S. Matthew's Gospel, only two examples of + Œ§ŒïŒõŒüŒ£ + occur, (viz. at ch. xxvi. 35 and xxvii. 2,)‚Äîin the former case the note has entirely lost its way in the process of transcription; standing where it has no business to appear. No Liturgical section ends thereabouts. I suspect that the transition (·ΩëœÄ·Ω≥œÅŒ≤Œ±œÉŒπœÇ) anciently made at ver. 39, was the thing to which the scribe desired to call attention.
425.
= Coisl. 20. This sumptuous MS., which has not been adapted for Church purposes, appears to me to be the work of the same scribe who produced Reg. 178, (the codex described above); but it exhibits a different text. Bound up with it are some leaves of the LXX of about the viiith century.
426.
End of the Lection for the Sunday before Epiphany.
427.
In S. Matthew's Gospel, I could find Œ§ŒïŒõŒüŒ£ so written only twice,‚Äîviz. at ch. ii. 23 and xxvi. 75: in S. Luke only once,‚Äîviz. at ch. viii. 39. These, in all three instances, are the concluding verses of famous Lessons,‚Äîviz. the Sunday after Christmas Day, the iiird Gospel of the Passion, the vith Sunday of S. Luke.
428.
This has already come before us in a different connection: (see p. 119): but it must needs be reproduced here; and this time, it shall be exhibited as faithfully as my notes permit.
429.

(1) In Evan. 282 (written A.D. 1176),‚Äîa codex which has been adapted to Lectionary purposes,‚Äîthe sign œÑŒµŒª and ŒµœÑ, strange to say, is inserted into the body of the Text, only at S. Mark xv. 47 and xvi. 8.

(2) Evan. 268, (a truly superb MS., evidently left unfinished, the pictures of the Evangelists only sketched in ink,) was never prepared for Lectionary purposes; which makes it the more remarkable that, between ·ºêœÜŒøŒ≤Œø·ø¶ŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥·Ω±œÅ and ·ºÄŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÇ, should be found inserted into the body of the text, œÑ·Ω≤. in gold.

(3) I have often met with copies of S. Matthew's, or of S. Luke's, or of S. John's Gospel, unfurnished with a subscription in which Œ§ŒïŒõŒüŒ£ occurs: but scarcely ever have I seen an instance of a Codex where the Gospel according to S. Mark was one of two, or of three from which it was wanting; much less where it stood alone in that respect. On the other hand, in the following Codices,‚ÄîEvan. 10: 22: 30: 293,‚ÄîS. Mark's is the only Gospel of the Four which is furnished with the subscription, + œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ [cross] or simply + œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ + .... In Evan. 282, S. Matthew's Gospel shares this peculiarity with S. Mark's.

430.

432.

435.
Observe, the peculiarity of the expression in this place of Eusebius consists entirely in his introduction of the words œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ. Had he merely said œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄŒ∫œÅŒπŒ≤·Ω¥ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ œÑ·Ω∏ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒµŒπ ·ºêŒΩ œÑŒø·øñœÇ Œª·ΩπŒ≥ŒøŒπœÇ Œ∫.œÑ.Œª. ... ·ºòŒΩ œÑŒø·ΩªœÑ·ø≥ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÉœáŒµŒ¥·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ ·ºÖœÄŒ±œÉŒπ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒøŒπœÇ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥·Ω≥Œ≥œÅŒ±œÄœÑŒ±Œπ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ,‚Äîthere would have been nothing extraordinary in the mode of expression. We should have been reminded of such places as the following in the writings of Eusebius himself:‚Äî·Ωâ ŒöŒª·ΩµŒºŒ∑œÇ ... Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ŒöŒøŒº·ΩπŒ¥ŒøœÖ œÑŒµŒªŒµœÖœÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒµŒπ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ œáœÅ·ΩπŒΩŒøœÖœÇ, (Hist. Eccl. lib. vi. c. 6.)‚Äî·ºπœÄœÄ·ΩπŒªœÖœÑŒøœÇ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∂ œÑ·Ω∏ œÄœÅ·ø∂œÑŒøŒΩ ·ºîœÑŒøœÇ Œ±·ΩêœÑŒøŒ∫œÅ·Ω±œÑŒøœÄŒøœÇ ·ºàŒªŒµŒæ·Ω±ŒΩŒ¥œÅŒøœÖ œÑŒø·Ω∫œÇ œáœÅ·ΩπŒΩŒøœÖœÇ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒµŒπ, (Ibid. c. 22. See the note of Valesius on the place.)‚ÄîOr this, referred to by Stephanus (in voce),‚Äî·ºôŒΩ·Ω∏œÇ Œ¥·æΩ ·ºîœÑŒπ ŒºŒΩŒ∑œÉŒ∏Œµ·Ω∂œÇ œÄŒµœÅŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œàœâ œÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ Œª·ΩπŒ≥ŒøŒΩ, (Praep. Evang. lib. vi. c. 10, [p. 280 c, ed. 1628].) But the substitution of œÑ·Ω∏ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ for œÑ·Ω∏ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ wants explaining; and can be only satisfactorily explained in one way.
