437.
Œ†·Ω±œÅŒµŒπŒºŒπ ŒΩ·ø¶ŒΩ ... œÄœÅ·Ω∏œÇ œÑ·ø∑ œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒµŒπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄ·Ω±ŒΩœÑŒøœÑŒµ œÑŒø·øñœÇ œÄ·æ∂œÉŒπ Œ∂Œ∑œÑŒø·ΩªŒºŒµŒΩŒ± [sic].‚ÄîMai, vol. iv. p. 255.
438.

‚ÄúConsentit autem nobis ad tractatum quem fecimus de scriptur√¢ Marci.‚Äù‚ÄîOrigen. (Opp. iii. 929 B.) Tractat. xxxv. in Matth. [I owe the reference to Cave (i. 118.) It seems to have escaped the vigilance of Huet.]‚ÄîThis serves to explain why Victor of Antioch's Catena on S. Mark was sometimes anciently attributed to Origen: as in Paris Cod. 703, [olim 2330, 958, and 1048: also 18.] where is read (at fol. 247), ·Ω®œÅŒπŒ≥·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖœÇ œÄœÅ·ΩπŒªŒøŒ≥ŒøœÇ Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ ·ºëœÅŒºŒ∑ŒΩŒµ·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ. Note, that Reg. 937 is but a (xvith cent.) counterpart of the preceding; which has been transcribed [xviiith cent.] in Par. Suppl. Grace. 40.

Possevinus [Apparat. Sac. ii. 542,] (quoted by Huet, Origeniana, p. 274) states that there is in the Library of C.C.C., Oxford, a Commentary on S. Mark's Gospel by Origen. The source of this misstatement has been acutely pointed out to me by the Rev. W. R. Churton. James, in his ‚ÄúEcloga Oxonio-Cantabrig.,‚Äù (1600, lib. i. p. 49,) mentions ‚ÄúHomiliae Origenis super Evangelio Marcae, Stabat ad monumentum.‚Äù‚ÄîRead instead, (with Rev. H. O. Coxe, ‚ÄúCat. Codd. MSS. C.C.C.;‚Äù [No. 142, 4,]) as follows:‚Äî‚ÄúOrigenis presb. Hom. in istud Johannis, Maria stabat ad monumentum,‚Äù &c. But what actually led Possevinus astray, I perceive, was James's consummation of his own blunder in lib. ii. p. 49,‚Äîwhich Possevinus has simply appropriated.

439.

So Chrysostom, speaking of the reading ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±Œ≤Œ±œÅ·Ω±.

Origen (iv. 140) says that not only œÉœáŒµŒ¥·Ω∏ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ œÄ·æ∂œÉŒπ œÑŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜŒøŒπœÇ, but also that apud Heracleonem, (who wrote within 50 years of S. John's death,) he found ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±ŒΩ·Ω∑Œ± written in S. John i. 28. Moved by geographical considerations, however, (as he explains,) for ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±ŒΩ·Ω∑Œ±, Origen proposes to read ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±Œ≤Œ±œÅ·Ω±.‚ÄîChrysostom (viii. 96 d), after noticing the former reading, declares,‚Äî·ΩÖœÉŒ± Œ¥·Ω≤ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ ·ºÄŒ∫œÅŒπŒ≤·Ω≥œÉœÑŒµœÅŒøŒΩ ·ºîœáŒµŒπ ·ºêŒΩ ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±Œ≤Œ±œÅ·Ω± œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ: but he goes on to reproduce Origen's reasoning;‚Äîthereby betraying himself.‚ÄîThe author of the Catena in Matth. (Cramer, i. 190-1) simply reproduces Chrysostom:‚ÄîœáœÅ·Ω¥ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œ≥ŒπŒΩ·ΩΩœÉŒ∫ŒµŒπŒΩ ·ΩÖœÑŒπ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄŒ∫œÅŒπŒ≤·øÜ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅ·Ω±œÜœâŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ ŒíŒ∑Œ∏Œ±Œ≤Œ±œÅ·Ω∞ œÄŒµœÅŒπ·Ω≥œáŒµŒπ. And so, other Scholia; until at last what was only due to the mistaken assiduity of Origen, became generally received as the reading of the ‚Äúmore accurate copies.‚Äù

A scholium on S. Luke xxiv. 13, in like manner, declares that the true reading of that place is not ‚Äú60‚Äù but ‚Äú160,‚Äù‚ÄîŒø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄŒ∫œÅŒπŒ≤·øÜ œÄŒµœÅŒπ·Ω≥œáŒµŒπ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·º° ·Ω®œÅŒπŒ≥·Ω≥ŒΩŒøœÖœÇ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒªŒ∑Œ∏Œµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ Œ≤ŒµŒ≤Œ±·Ω∑œâœÉŒπœÇ. Accordingly, Eusebius also reads the place in the same erroneous way.

448.

Accordingly, in Cod. Evan. 266 (= Paris Reg. 67) is read, at S. Mark xvi. 8 (fol. 125), as follows:‚Äî·ºêœÜŒøŒ≤Œø·ø¶ŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥·Ω±œÅ. [then, rubro,] œÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œí·æΩ ·ºëœâŒ∏·Ω∑ŒΩŒøœÖ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ∫œÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫·øÜœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒºœÖœÅŒøœÜ·ΩπœÅœâŒΩ. ·ºÄœÅœá·Ωµ. [then the text:] ·ºàŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω±œÇ Œ∫.œÑ.Œª. ... After ver. 20, (at fol. 126 of the same Codex) is found the following concluding rubric:‚ÄîœÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œì·æΩ ·ºëœâŒ∏·Ω∑ŒΩŒøœÖ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒª·Ω∑ŒøœÖ.

In the same place, (viz. at the end of S. Mark's Gospel,) is found in another Codex (Evan. 7 = Paris Reg. 71,) the following rubric:‚ÄîœÑ·Ω≥ŒªŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÑœÅ·Ω∑œÑŒøœÖ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ºëœâŒ∏·Ω∑ŒΩŒøœÖ, Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ΩÑœÅŒ∏œÅŒøœÖ œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œª·ΩµœàŒµœâœÇ.

449.
R. Payne Smith's Catal. p. 146.
450.

Cod. 27 (xi) is not provided with any lectionary apparatus, and is written continuously throughout: and yet at S. Mark xvi. 9 a fresh paragraph is observed to commence.

Not dissimilar is the phenomenon recorded in respect of some copies of the Armenian version. ‚ÄúThe Armenian, in the edition of Zohrab, separates the concluding 12 verses from the rest of the Gospel.... Many of the oldest MSS., after the words ·ºêœÜŒøŒ≤Œø·ø¶ŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥·Ω±œÅ, put the final Œï·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ, and then give the additional verses with a new superscription.‚Äù (Tregelles, Printed Text, p. 253).... We are now in a position to understand the Armenian evidence, which has been described above, at p. 36, as well as to estimate its exact value.

451.
Euseb. apud Mai, iv. p. 264 = p. 287. Again at p. 289-90.‚ÄîSo also the author of the 2nd Homily on the Resurr. (Greg. Nyss. Opp. iii. 411-2.)‚ÄîAnd see the third of the fragments ascribed to Polycarp. Patres Apostol., (ed. Jacobson) ii. p. 515.
452.
I believe this will be found to be the invariable order of the Gospels in the Lectionaries.
453.
This is the case for instance in Evan. 15 (= Reg. 64). See fol. 98 b.
454.

I allude of course to Matthaei's Cod. g. (See the note in his N. T. vol. ix. p. 228.) Whether or no the learned critic was right in his conjecture ‚Äúaliquot folia excidisse,‚Äù matters nothing. The left hand page ends at the words ·ºêœÜŒøŒ≤Œø·ø¶ŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥·Ω±œÅ. Now, if œÑŒµŒªŒøœÇ had followed, how obvious would have been the inference that the Gospel itself of S. Mark had come to an end there!

Note, that in the Codex Bez√¶ (D), S. Mark's Gospel ends at ver. 15: in the Gothic Codex Argenteus, at ver. 11. The Codex Vercell. (a) proves to be imperfect from ch. xv. 15; Cod. Veron. (b) from xiii. 24; Cod. Brix. (f) from xiv. 70.

Ita, ut de 30 fere Codd. certe tres videamus, 22 habet: ·ºêœÜŒøŒ≤ŒøœÖŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥Œ±œÅ + œÑŒµŒªŒøœÇ. Nam in locis œÄŒ±œÅŒµŒ≥Œ≥œÅ·Ω±œÄœÑŒøŒπœÇ, etiam multo brevioribus, quo plures sunt Codices, eo plures quoque sunt varietates. Comparetur modo Act. xv. 18, Matth. viii. 13, et loca similia.‚Äù‚ÄîC. F. Matthaei's Nov. Test. (1788) vol. ii. p. 271.
479.
Speaking of the abrupt termination of the second Gospel at ver. 8, Dr. Tregelles asks,‚Äî‚ÄúWould this have been transmitted as a fact by good witnesses, if there had not been real grounds for regarding it to be true?‚Äù‚Äî(Printed Text, p. 257.) Certainly not, we answer. But where are the ‚Äúgood witnesses‚Äù of the ‚Äútransmitted fact?‚Äù There is not so much as one.

496.

497.
Will it be believed that Tischendorf accordingly rejects that verse also as spurious; and brings the fourth Gospel to an end at ver. 24, as he brings the second Gospel to an end at ver. 8? For my own part,‚Äîhaving (through the kindness and liberality of the Keeper of the Imperial MSS. at S. Petersburg, aided by the good offices of my friend, the Rev. A. S. Thompson, Chaplain at S. Petersburg,) obtained a photograph of the last page of S. John's Gospel,‚ÄîI must be allowed altogether to call in question the accuracy of Dr. Tischendorf's judgment in this particular. The utmost which can be allowed is that the Scribe may have possibly changed his pen, or been called away from his task, just before bringing the fourth Gospel to a close.
498.
See Chap. IX.
499.
Chapter X.
500.
Pseudo-Gregory Thaumaturgus, Pseudo-Basil, Patricius, and Marius Mercator, are designedly omitted in this enumeration.
501.
Codex A,‚Äî·ΩïŒºŒΩŒøœÇ ·ºëœâŒ∏ŒπŒΩ·ΩπœÇ at the end of the Psalms.
502.
The old Latin Interpreter of Origen's Commentary on S. Matthew seems to have found in Origen's text a quotation from S. Luke ii. 14 which is not represented in the extant Greek text of Origen. Here also we are presented with ‚Äúhominibus bonae voluntatis.‚Äù (Opp. iii. 537 C). We can say nothing to such second-hand evidence.
503.
Consider his exactly similar method concerning Eph. i. 1. (Supr√†, pp. 96-99.)

506.

P.S. I avail myself of this blank space to introduce a passage from Theophylact (A.D. 1077) which should have obtained notice in a much earlier page:‚Äî·ºàŒΩŒ±œÉœÑ·Ω∞œÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ ·ΩÅ ·º∏Œ∑œÉŒø·ø¶œÇ; ·ºêŒΩœÑŒ±·ø¶Œ∏Œ± œÉœÑ·Ω∑ŒæŒøŒΩ, Œµ·º∂œÑŒ± Œµ·º±œÄ·Ω≥; œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ œÄœÅ·ΩΩœÑ·øá œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ ŒúŒ±œÅ·Ω∑·æ≥ œÑ·øá ŒúŒ±Œ≥Œ¥Œ±ŒªŒ∑ŒΩ·øá. Œø·Ωê Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω≥œÉœÑŒ∑ œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ (œÑ·Ω∑œÇ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ Œø·º¥Œ¥Œµ œÄ·ΩπœÑŒµ ·ºÄŒΩ·Ω≥œÉœÑŒ∑;) ·ºÄŒªŒª·æΩ ·ºêœÜ·Ω±ŒΩŒ∑ œÄœÅœâ·Ω∑ Œ∫œÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫·øá ·º°Œº·Ω≥œÅ·æ≥ (Œ±·ΩîœÑŒ∑ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·º° œÄœÅ·ΩΩœÑŒ∑ œÑŒø·ø¶ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑŒøœÖ, œÑŒøœÖœÑ·Ω≥œÉœÑŒπ, œÑ·øÜœÇ ·ºëŒ≤Œ¥ŒøŒº·Ω±Œ¥ŒøœÇ,) ·º•ŒΩ ·ºÑŒΩœâ ·ºêŒ∫·Ω±ŒªŒµœÉŒµ Œº·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ œÉŒ±Œ≤Œ≤·Ω±œÑœâŒΩ; [Opp. vol. i. p. 263 C.

It must be superfluous to point out that Theophylact also,‚Äîlike Victor, Jerome, and Hesychius,‚Äîis here only reproducing Eusebius. See above, p. 66, note (c).

507.
Kollar, (editing Lambecius,‚Äîiii. 159, 114,) expresses the same opinion.‚ÄîHuet (Origeniana, lib. iii. c. 4, pp. 274-5,) has a brief and unsatisfactory dissertation on the same subject; but he arrives at a far shrewder conclusion.
508.
The copies which I have seen, are headed,‚ÄîŒíŒôŒöŒ§ŒüŒ°ŒüŒ£ (sometimes ŒíŒôŒöŒ§Œ©Œ°ŒüŒ£) Œ†Œ°ŒïŒ£ŒíŒ•Œ§ŒïŒ°ŒüŒ• ŒëŒùŒ§ŒôŒüŒßŒïŒôŒëŒ£ ŒïŒ°ŒúŒóŒùŒïŒôŒë ŒïŒôŒ£ Œ§Œü ŒöŒëŒ§Œë ŒúŒëŒ°ŒöŒüŒù ŒïŒ•ŒëŒìŒìŒïŒõŒôŒüŒù; or with words precisely to that effect. Very often no Author's name is given. Rarely is the Commentary assigned to Cyril, Origen, &c.‚ÄîVide infr√†, No. iii, xii, xiv, xix, xlviii. Also, No. xlvii (comp, xxviii.)
509.
Victoris Antiocheni in Marcum, et Titi Bostrorum Episcopi in Evangelium Lucae commentarii; ante hac quidem nunquam in lucem editi, nunc vero studio et oper√¢ Theodori Peltani luce simul et Latinitate donati. Ingolstadt. 1580, 8vo. pp. 510.
510.
‚ÄúEx hoc ego, quasi metallo triplici, una conflata massa, inde annulos formavi, quos singulos Evangelici contextus articulis aptatos, inter seque morsu ac nexu mutuo commissos, in torquem producerem, quo, si possem consequi, sancto Evangelistae Marco decus et ornamentum adderetur.‚Äù‚ÄîPr√¶fatio: from which the particulars in the text are obtained.
511.
ŒíŒôŒöŒ§Œ©Œ°ŒüŒ£ œÄœÅŒµœÉŒ≤œÖœÑ·Ω≥œÅŒøœÖ ·ºàŒΩœÑŒπŒøœáŒµ·Ω∑Œ±œÇ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÑŒªŒªœâŒΩ œÑŒπŒΩ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÅŒ≥·Ω∑œâŒΩ œÄŒ±œÑ·Ω≥œÅœâŒΩ ·ºêŒæ·ΩµœÉŒ∑œÉŒπœÇ Œµ·º∞œÇ œÑ·Ω∏ Œ∫Œ±œÑ·Ω∞ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ ·ºÖŒ≥ŒπŒøŒΩ Œµ·ΩêŒ±Œ≥Œ≥·Ω≥ŒªŒπŒøŒΩ: ex Codd. Mosqq. edidit C. F. Matth√¶i, Mosquae, 1775.
512.
P. xxvii-xxviii.
513.
To understand what is alluded to, the reader should compare the upper and the lower half of p. 442 in Cramer: noting that he has one and the same annotation before him; but diversely exhibited. (The lower part of the page is taken from Cod. 178.) Besides transposing the sentences, the author of Cod. 178 has suppressed the reference to Chrysostom, and omitted the name of Apolinarius in line 10. (Compare Field's ed. of Chrys. iii. 529, top of the page.)
514.
Thus the two notes on p. 440 are found substantially to agree with the note on p. 441, which = Chrys. p. 527. See also infr√†, p. 289.
515.
Let any one, with Mai's edition of the ‚ÄúQuaestiones ad Marinum‚Äù of Eusebius before him, note how mercilessly they are abridged, mutilated, amputated by subsequent writers. Compare for instance p. 257 with Cramer's ‚ÄúCatenae,‚Äù i. p. 251-2; and this again with the ‚ÄúCatena in Joannem‚Äù of Corderius, p. 448-9.
516.

523.
In p. 418,‚Äî·ΩÅ œÑ·øÜœÇ Œ≤Œ±œÉŒπŒª·Ω∑Œ¥ŒøœÇ œÄ·ΩπŒªŒµœâœÇ ·ºêœÄ·Ω∑œÉŒ∫ŒøœÄŒøœÇ ·º∏œâ·Ω±ŒΩŒΩŒ∑œÇ. For instances of quotation from Chrysostom, comp. V. A. p. 315 with Chrys. pp. 398-9: p. 376 with Chrys. pp. 227-8: p. 420 with Chrys. p. 447, &c.
524.
Take for example Victor's Commentary on the stilling of the storm (pp. 312-3), which is merely an abridged version of the first part of Chrysostom's 28th Homily on S. Matthew (pp. 395-8); about 45 lines being left out. Observe Victor's method however. Chrysostom begins as follows:‚Äî·Ωâ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œø·ΩñŒΩ ŒõŒøœÖŒ∫·æ∂œÇ, ·ºÄœÄŒ±ŒªŒª·Ω±œÑœÑœâŒΩ ·ºëŒ±œÖœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ºÄœÄŒ±ŒπœÑŒ∑Œ∏·øÜŒΩŒ±Œπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œáœÅ·ΩπŒΩœâŒΩ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÑ·Ω±ŒæŒπŒΩ, Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ Œµ·º∂œÄŒµŒΩ. (Then follows S. Luke viii. 22.) Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ΩÅ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøœÇ ·ΩÅŒºŒø·Ω∑œâœÇ. Œü·ΩóœÑŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œø·Ωêœá Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ; ·ºÄŒªŒª·Ω∞ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩœÑŒ±·ø¶Œ∏Œ± Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÑŒ∑œÅŒµ·øñ. Victor, because he had S. Mark (not S. Matthew) to comment upon, begins thus:‚Äî·Ωâ Œº·Ω≤ŒΩ Œú·Ω±œÅŒ∫ŒøœÇ ·ºÄœÄŒ±ŒªŒª·Ω±œÑœÑœâŒΩ ·ºëŒ±œÖœÑ·Ω∏ŒΩ œÑŒø·ø¶ ·ºÄœÄŒ±ŒπœÑŒ∑Œ∏·øÜŒΩŒ±Œπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œáœÅ·ΩπŒΩœâŒΩ œÑ·Ω¥ŒΩ œÑ·Ω±ŒæŒπŒΩ, Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ Œµ·º∂œÄŒµŒΩ, ·ΩÅŒºŒø·Ω∑œâœÇ Œ¥·Ω≤ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ΩÅ ŒõŒø·ø¶Œ∫Œ±œÇ; ·ΩÅ Œ¥·Ω≤ ŒúŒ±œÑŒ∏Œ±·øñŒøœÇ Œø·Ωêœá Œø·ΩïœÑœâœÇ; ·ºÄŒªŒª·Ω∞ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœÖŒ∏·Ω∑Œ±ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩœÑŒ±·ø¶Œ∏Œ± Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÑŒ∑œÅŒµ·øñ.
525.
e.g. V. A. p. 422 (from ·ΩÅ Œº·Ω≥ŒΩ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ to ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω≥ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ) = Chrys. p. 460. Observe the next paragraph also, (p. 423,) begins, ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ.‚ÄîSo again, V. A. pp. 426-7 = Chrys. pp. 473-6: where ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω≥ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπ, at the foot of p. 427 introduces a quotation from Origen, as appears from Possinus, p. 324‚ÄîSee also p. 209, line 1,‚Äîwhich is from Chrys. p. 130,‚Äî·º§ ·Ω°œÇ ·ΩÅ ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ being the next words.‚ÄîThe first three lines in p. 316 = Chrys. p. 399. Then follows, ·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω≥ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ. See also pp. 392: 407 (œÜŒ±œÉ·Ω∑ œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ‚Äî·ºïœÑŒµœÅŒøœÇ Œ¥·Ω≥ œÜŒ∑œÉŒπŒΩ): pp. 415 and 433. 529.

530.

532.
Reg. 177 = A: 178 = B: 230 = C.‚ÄîCoisl. 19 = D: 20 = E: 21 = F: 22 = G: 24 = H.‚ÄîMatthaei's d or D = I: his e or E = J: his 12 = K: his a or A = L.‚ÄîVat. 358 = M: 756 = N: 757 = O: 1229 = P: 1446 = Q.‚ÄîVind. Koll. 4 Forlos. 5 = R.‚ÄîXav. de Zelada = S.‚ÄîLaur. 18 = T: 34 = U.‚ÄîVenet. 27 = V.‚ÄîVind. Lamb. 38 = W : 39 = X.
533.
So B-E (which I chiefly follow) begins,‚ÄîŒ§Œø Œ¥Œµ Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑŒ±œÇ.
534.
B begins thus,‚ÄîŒïŒπ Œ¥Œµ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒø Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑŒ±œÇ Œ¥Œµ œÄœÅœâŒπ ŒºŒµœÑŒ± œÑŒ± ŒµœÄŒπœÜŒµœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒ± œÄŒ±œÅŒ±. It is at this word (œÄŒ±œÅŒ±) that most copies of the present scholion (A, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X) begin.
535.
So far (except in its opening phrase) E. But C, D, F, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O, P, T, begin,‚ÄîŒ†Œ±œÅŒ± œÄŒªŒµŒπœÉœÑŒøŒπœÇ Œ±ŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±œÜŒøŒπœÇ ŒøœÖ Œ∫ŒµŒπŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ [I, ŒøœÖ Œ∫ŒµŒπœÑŒ±Œπ: J, ŒøœÖŒ∫ Œ∑ŒΩ Œ¥Œµ] œÑŒ±œÖœÑŒ± œÑŒ± [M, O, T om. œÑŒ±] ŒµœÄŒπœÜŒµœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒ± ŒµŒΩ [D, F, H om. ŒµŒΩ] œÑ·ø≥ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ± ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ [B, ŒµŒΩ œÑœâ œÄŒ±œÅŒøŒΩœÑŒπ] ŒµœÖŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπ·ø≥.
536.
So I, J, K, L, and H. P proceeds,‚ÄîœâœÇ ŒΩŒøŒ∏Œ± ŒΩŒøŒºŒπœÉŒ∏ŒµŒΩœÑŒ± œÑŒπœÉŒπŒΩ ŒµŒπŒΩŒ±Œπ. But B, C, D, E, F, G, M, N, O, T exhibit,‚ÄîœâœÇ ŒΩŒøŒ∏Œ± ŒΩŒøŒºŒπœÉŒ±ŒΩœÑŒµœÇ Œ±œÖœÑŒ± œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ [B om. œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ] ŒµŒπŒΩŒ±Œπ. On the other hand, A and Q begin and proceed as follows,‚ÄîŒ†Œ±œÅŒ± œÄŒªŒµŒπœÉœÑŒøŒπœÇ Œ±ŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±œÜŒøŒπœÇ œÑŒ±œÖœÑŒ± œÑŒ± [Q om. œÑŒ±] ŒµœÄŒπœÜŒµœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒ± ŒµŒΩ [A om. ŒµŒΩ] œÑ·ø≥ Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ± ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫ŒøŒΩ ŒµœÖŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπ·ø≥ œâœÇ ŒΩŒøŒ∏Œ± ŒΩŒøŒºŒπœÉŒ±ŒΩœÑŒµœÇ œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ [Q, œÑŒπŒΩŒ±œÇ (a clerical error): A om. œÑŒπŒΩŒµœÇ] ŒøœÖŒ∫ ŒµŒ∏Œ∑Œ∫Œ±ŒΩ.
537.
So B, except that it omits œâœÇ. So also, A, D, E, F, G, H, J, M, N, O, P, Q, T, except that they begin the sentence, Œ∑ŒºŒµŒπœÇ Œ¥Œµ.
538.
So D, E, F, G, H, J, M, N, O, P, T: also B and Q, except that they prefix Œ∫Œ±Œπ to Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ± œÑŒø Œ†. B is peculiar in reading,‚ÄîœâœÇ ŒµœáŒµŒπ Œ∑ Œ±ŒªŒ∑Œ∏ŒµŒπŒ± ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫ŒøœÖ (transposing ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫ŒøœÖ): while C and P read,‚ÄîŒøŒºœâœÇ Œ∑ŒºŒµŒπœÇ ŒµŒæ Œ±Œ∫œÅŒπŒ≤œâŒΩ Œ±ŒΩœÑŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±œÜœâŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ œÄŒªŒµŒπœÉœÑœâŒΩ ŒøœÖ ŒºŒ∑ŒΩ Œ±ŒªŒªŒ± Œ∫Œ±Œπ ŒµŒΩ œÑ·ø≥ Œ†Œ±ŒªŒ±ŒπœÉœÑŒπŒΩŒ±Œπ·ø≥ ŒµœÖŒ±Œ≥Œ≥ŒµŒªŒπ·ø≥ ŒúŒ±œÅŒ∫ŒøœÖ ŒµœÖœÅŒøŒΩœÑŒµœÇ Œ±œÖœÑŒ± œâœÇ ŒµœáŒµŒπ Œ∑ Œ±ŒªŒ∑Œ∏ŒµŒπŒ± œÉœÖŒΩœÑŒµŒ∏ŒµŒπŒ∫Œ±ŒºŒµŒΩ.
539.
So all, apparently: except that P reads ŒµŒºœÜŒµœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒ∑ŒΩ for ŒµœÄŒπœÜŒµœÅŒøŒºŒµŒΩŒ∑ŒΩ; and M, after Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑŒ±œÉŒπŒΩ inserts ŒµŒ¥Œ∑ŒªœâœÉŒ±ŒºŒµŒΩ, with a point (.) before ŒºŒµœÑŒ±: while C and P (after Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑŒ±œÇŒπŒΩ,) proceed,‚ÄîŒ∫Œ±Œπ œÑŒ∑ŒΩ [C, ŒµŒπœÑŒ±] Œ±ŒΩŒ±ŒªŒ∑œàŒπŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ∫Œ±Œ∏ŒµŒ¥œÅŒ±ŒΩ ŒµŒ∫ Œ¥ŒµŒæŒπœâŒΩ œÑŒøœÖ Œ†Œ±œÑœÅŒøœÇ ·ø≥ œÄœÅŒµœÄŒµŒπ Œ∑ Œ¥ŒøŒæŒ± Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ∑ œÑŒπŒºŒ∑ ŒΩœÖŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ ŒµŒπœÇ œÑŒøœÖœÇ Œ±ŒπœâŒΩŒ±œÇ. Œ±ŒºŒ∑ŒΩ. But J [and I think, H] (after Œ≥Œ±œÅ) proceeds,‚ÄîŒ¥ŒπŒø Œ¥ŒøŒæŒ±ŒΩ Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÄŒµŒºœàœâŒºŒµŒΩ œÑ·ø≥ Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÉœÑŒ±ŒΩœÑŒπ ŒµŒ∫ ŒΩŒµŒ∫œÅœâŒΩ ŒßœÅŒπœÉœÑ·ø≥ œÑ·ø≥ ŒòŒµ·ø≥ Œ∑ŒºœâŒΩ Œ±ŒºŒ± œÑ·ø≥ Œ±ŒΩŒ±œÅœá·ø≥ Œ†Œ±œÑœÅŒπ Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ∂œâŒøœÄŒøŒπ·ø≥ Œ†ŒΩŒµœÖŒºŒ±œÑŒπ ŒΩœÖŒΩ Œ∫Œ±Œπ Œ±ŒµŒπ Œ∫Œ±Œπ ŒµŒπœÇ œÑŒøœÖœÇ Œ±ŒπœâŒΩŒ±œÇ œÑœâŒΩ Œ±ŒπœâŒΩœâŒΩ. Œ±ŒºŒ∑ŒΩ.
540.
So B. All, except B, C, H, J, P seem to end at ŒµœÜŒøŒ≤ŒøœÖŒΩœÑŒø Œ≥Œ±œÅ.
541.
e.g. Œø·ΩêŒ∫ ·º¶ŒΩ Œ¥·Ω≥ for Œø·Ωê Œ∫Œµ·øñŒΩœÑŒ±Œπ.
542.
Jerome evidently supposed that Ammonius was the author of the Canons as well:‚Äî‚ÄúCanones quos Eusebius Caesariensis Episcopus Alexandrinum secutus Ammonium in decem numeros ordinavit, sicut in Graeco habentur expressimus.‚Äù (Ad Papam Damasum. Epist.) And again: ‚ÄúAmmonius ... Evangelicos Canones excogitavit quos postea secutus est Eusebius Caesariensis.‚Äù (De Viris Illustr. c. 55 [Opp. ii. 881.])‚ÄîSee above, p. 128.
543.
There was published at the University Press in 1805, a handsome quarto volume (pp. 216) entitled Harmonia quatuor Evangeliorum juxta Sectiones Ammonianas et Eusebii Canones. It is merely the contents of the X Canons of Eusebius printed in extenso,‚Äîand of course is no ‚ÄúHarmony‚Äù at all. It would have been a really useful book, notwithstanding; but that the editor, strange to say, has omitted to number the sections.
544.
This last ¬ß according to Tischendorf's ed. of the Eusebian Canons.
545.
Thus, certain disputed passages of importance are proved to have been recognised at least by Eusebius. Our Lord's Agony in the Garden for instance, (S. Luke xxii. 43, 44‚Äîwanting in Cod. B,) is by him numbered ¬ß 283: and that often rejected verse, S. Mark xv. 28, he certainly numbered ¬ß 216,‚Äîwhatever Tischendorf may say to the contrary. (See p. 203.)
546.
It is obvious to suggest that, (1) whereas our Marginal References follow the order of the Sacred Books, they ought rather to stand in the order of their importance, or at least of their relevancy to the matter in hand:‚Äîand that, (2) actual Quotations, and even Allusions to other parts of Scripture when they are undeniable, should be referred to in some distinguishing way. It is also certain that, (3) to a far greater extent than at present, sets of References might be kept together; not scattered about in small parcels over the whole Book.‚ÄîAbove all, (as the point most pertinent to the present occasion,) (4) it is to be wished that strictly parallel places in the Gospels might be distinguished from those which are illustrative only, or are merely recalled by their similarity of subject or expression. All this would admit of interesting and useful illustration. While on this subject, let me ask,‚ÄîWhy is it no longer possible to purchase a Bible with References to the Apocrypha? Who does not miss the reference to ‚ÄúEcclus. xliii. 11, 12‚Äù at Gen. ix. 14? Who can afford to do without the reference to ‚Äú1 Macc. iv. 59‚Äù at S. John x. 22?
547.
Mai, vol. iv. p. 287. See also p. 293.
548.
Tischendorf says 19 only.
549.
Tischendorf says 96 only.
550.
Tischendorf says 13 only.
551.
Scrivener specifics the following Codd. C, F, H, I, P, Q, R, W6, Y, Z, 54, 59, 60, 68, 440, iscr, sscr. Also D and K. (Cod. Bez√¶, p. xx, and Introd. pp. 51, 2.) Add Evan. 117: (but I think not 263.)
552.

553.

555.

556.

557.

558.

559.
It will be observed that, according to the Syrian scheme, every verse of S. Mark xvi, from ver. 8 to ver. 15 inclusive, constitutes an independent section (¬ß¬ß 281-288): ver. 16-18 another (¬ß 289); and verr. 19-20, another (¬ß 290), which is the last. The Greek scheme, as a rule, makes independent sections of verr. 8, 9, 14, 19, 20; but throws together ver. 10-11: 12-13: 15-16: 17-18. (Vide infr√†, p. 311.)
560.

Note that ¬ß 392/9 = S. Luke xxiv. 12: ¬ß 394/10 = ver. 18-34: ¬ß 395/8 = ver. 35: ¬ß 396/9 is incomplete. [Dr. Wright supplies the lacune for me, thus: ¬ß 396/9 = ver. 36-41 (down to Œ∏Œ±œÖŒºŒ±Œ∂·ΩπŒΩœÑœâŒΩ): ¬ß 397/9 = Œµ·º∂œÄŒµŒΩ Œ±·ΩêœÑŒø·øñœÇ down to the end of ver. 41: ¬ß 398/9 = ver. 42: ¬ß 399/9 = ver. 43: ¬ß 400/10 = ver. 44-50: ¬ß 401/8 = 51: ¬ß 402/10 = ver. 52, 3.

Critical readers will be interested in comparing, or rather contrasting, the Sectional system of a Syriac MS. with that which prevails in all Greek Codices. S. John's ¬ß 248/1 = xx. 18: his ¬ß 249/9 = ver. 19 to Œµ·º∞œÅ·ΩµŒΩŒ∑ ·ΩëŒº·øñŒΩ in ver. 21: his $ 250/7 = ver. 21 (Œ∫Œ±Œ∏·ΩΩœÇ to the end of the verse): his ¬ß 251/10 = ver. 22: his ¬ß 252/7 = ver. 23: his ¬ß 253/[10] = ver. 24-5: his ¬ß 254/[9] = ver. 26-7: his ¬ß 255/10 = ver. 28 to the end of xxi. 4: his ¬ß 256/9 = xxi. 5: his ¬ß 257/9 = xxi. 6 (to Œµ·ΩëœÅ·ΩµœÉŒµœÑŒµ): his ¬ß 258/9 = ver. 6, (·ºîŒ≤Œ±ŒªŒøŒΩ to the end): his ¬ß 259/[10] = ver. 7, 8: his ¬ß 260/[9] = ver. 9: his ¬ß 261/[10] = ver. 10: his ¬ß 262/9 = ver. 11: his ¬ß 263/9 = first half of ver. 12: his ¬ß 264/10 is incomplete.

[But Dr. Wright, (remarking that in his MSS., which are evidently the correcter ones, 263/10 stands opposite the middle of ver. 12 [Œø·ΩêŒ¥Œµ·Ω∂œÇ ·ºêœÑ·ΩπŒªŒºŒ±], and 264/9 opposite ver. 13 [·ºîœÅœáŒµœÑŒ±Œπ Œø·ΩñŒΩ],) proceeds to supply the lacune for me, thus: ¬ß 264/9 = ver. 13: ¬ß 265/10 = ver. 14-5 (down to œÜŒπŒª·ø∂ œÉŒµ; Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµŒπ Œ±œÖœÑ·ø∑): ¬ß 266/9 = Œ≤·ΩπœÉŒ∫Œµ œÑ·Ω∞ ·ºÄœÅŒΩ·Ω∑Œ± ŒºŒøœÖ, (end of ver. 15): ¬ß 267/10 = ver. 16 (down to œÜŒπŒª·ø∂ œÉŒµ): ¬ß 268/9 = Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµŒπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∑, Œ†Œø·Ω∑ŒºŒ±ŒπŒΩŒµ œÑ·Ω∞ œÄœÅ·ΩπŒ≤Œ±œÑŒ± ŒºŒøœÖ (end of ver. 16): ¬ß 269/10 = ver. 17 (down to œÜŒπŒª·ø∂ œÉŒµ): ¬ß 270/9 = Œª·Ω≥Œ≥ŒµŒπ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·ø∑ ·ΩÅ ·º∏., Œ≤. œÑ·Ω∞ œÄ. ŒºŒøœÖ (end of ver. 17): ¬ß 271/10 = ver. 18 to 25.

561.
‚ÄúI have examined for your purposes, Add. 14,449; 14,457; 14,458; and 7,157. The first three are Nos. lxix, lxx, and lxxi, in my own Catalogue: the last, a Nestorian MS., is No. xiii in the old Catalogue of Forshall and Rosen (London, 1838). All four agree in their numeration.‚Äù
562.
See the preceding note.‚ÄîAvailing myself of the reference given me by my learned correspondent, I read as follows in the Catalogue:‚Äî‚ÄúInter ipsa textus verba, numeris viridi colore pictis, notatur Canon harmoniae Eusebianae, ad quem quaevis sectio referenda est. Sic, [glyph] [i.e. 1] indicat canonem in quo omnes Evangelistae concurrunt,‚Äù &c. &c.
563.

573.
Œ£Œ∑ŒºŒµ·Ω∑œâœÉŒπœÇ is what we call an ‚ÄúAnnotation.‚Äù [On the sign in the text, see the Catalogue of MSS. in the Turin Library, P. i. p. 93.] On the word, and on œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµŒπŒø·ø¶œÉŒ∏Œ±Œπ, (consider 2 Thess. iii. 14,) see the interesting remarks of Huet, Origeniana, iii. ¬ß i. 4. (at the end of vol. iv. of Origen's Opp. p. 292-3.)‚ÄîEusebius (Hist. Eccl. v. 20) uses œÉŒ∑ŒºŒµ·Ω∑œâœÉŒπœÇ in this sense. (See the note of Valesius.) But it is plain from the rendering of Jerome and Rufinus (subscriptio), that it often denoted a ‚Äúsignature,‚Äù or signing of the name. Eusebius so employs the word in lib. v. 19 ad fin.
574.
He was Patriarch of Antioch, A.D. 512-9.‚ÄîThe extract (made by Petrus junior, Monophysite Patriarch of Antioch, A.D. 578,) purports to be derived from the 26th Epistle, (Book 9,) which Severus addressed to Thomas Bp. of Germanicia after his exile. See Assemani, Bibl. Orient. vol. ii. pp. 81-2.
575.
I cannot find the place in Cyril. I suppose it occurs in a lost Commentary of this Father,‚Äîwhose Works by the way are miserably indexed.
576.

Section 2.

Information about the Mission of Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢

Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ is synonymous with the free distribution of electronic works in formats readable by the widest variety of computers including obsolete, old, middle-aged and new computers. It exists because of the efforts of hundreds of volunteers and donations from people in all walks of life.

Volunteers and financial support to provide volunteers with the assistance they need, is critical to reaching Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢'s goals and ensuring that the Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ collection will remain freely available for generations to come. In 2001, the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure and permanent future for Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ and future generations. To learn more about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation and how your efforts and donations can help, see Sections 3 and 4 and the Foundation web page at http://www.pglaf.org.

Section 4.

Information about Donations to the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation

Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ depends upon and cannot survive without wide spread public support and donations to carry out its mission of increasing the number of public domain and licensed works that can be freely distributed in machine readable form accessible by the widest array of equipment including outdated equipment. Many small donations ($1 to $5,000) are particularly important to maintaining tax exempt status with the IRS.

The Foundation is committed to complying with the laws regulating charities and charitable donations in all 50 states of the United States. Compliance requirements are not uniform and it takes a considerable effort, much paperwork and many fees to meet and keep up with these requirements. We do not solicit donations in locations where we have not received written confirmation of compliance. To SEND DONATIONS or determine the status of compliance for any particular state visit http://www.gutenberg.org/fundraising/donate

While we cannot and do not solicit contributions from states where we have not met the solicitation requirements, we know of no prohibition against accepting unsolicited donations from donors in such states who approach us with offers to donate.

International donations are gratefully accepted, but we cannot make any statements concerning tax treatment of donations received from outside the United States. U.S. laws alone swamp our small staff.

Please check the Project Gutenberg Web pages for current donation methods and addresses. Donations are accepted in a number of other ways including checks, online payments and credit card donations. To donate, please visit: http://www.gutenberg.org/fundraising/donate

Section 5.

General Information About Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ electronic works.

Professor Michael S. Hart is the originator of the Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ concept of a library of electronic works that could be freely shared with anyone. For thirty years, he produced and distributed Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ eBooks with only a loose network of volunteer support.

Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢ eBooks are often created from several printed editions, all of which are confirmed as Public Domain in the U.S. unless a copyright notice is included. Thus, we do not necessarily keep eBooks in compliance with any particular paper edition.

Each eBook is in a subdirectory of the same number as the eBook's eBook number, often in several formats including plain vanilla ASCII, compressed (zipped), HTML and others.

Corrected editions of our eBooks replace the old file and take over the old filename and etext number. The replaced older file is renamed. Versions based on separate sources are treated as new eBooks receiving new filenames and etext numbers.

Most people start at our Web site which has the main PG search facility: http://www.gutenberg.org

This Web site includes information about Project Gutenberg‚Ñ¢, including how to make donations to the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation, how to help produce our new eBooks, and how to subscribe to our email newsletter to hear about new eBooks.
